title: 이/가 [i/ga] (Subject markers)
short_explanation: These are subject markers used to identify and emphasize the subject in a sentence.
long_explanation: '이/가 [i/ga]' are postpositions used in Korean to mark the subject of a sentence. They are attached right after a noun to indicate that the noun is the subject. The choice between '이' and '가' depends on whether the noun ends in a consonant or a vowel. If the noun ends with a consonant, '이' is used. If the noun ends with a vowel, '가' is used.
formation: Noun + 이/가 + rest of the sentence

examples.kr: 나는 사과를 먹어요, 근데 친구는 오렌지가 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Naneun sagwareul meogeoyo, geunde chinguneun orenjiga joayo.
examples.en: I eat apples, but my friend likes oranges.

examples.kr: 저의 강아지가 소파 위에 뛰어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoi gangajiga sopa wie ttwieoyo.
examples.en: My dog jumps on the sofa.

examples.kr: 이 책이 제일 재미있어요.
examples.romaji: I chaegi jeil jaemiisseoyo.
examples.en: This book is the most fun.

examples.kr: 당신이 좋아하는 음식이 뭔가요?
examples.romaji: Dangsini joahaneun eumsigi mwongayo?
examples.en: What is the food that you like?

title: 은/는 [eun/neun] (Topic markers)
short_explanation: Used to mark the topic of a sentence or to contrast an idea or subject.
long_explanation: '은/는 [eun/neun]' are particle markers in Korean used to introduce or highlight the topic of a sentence. They follow a noun to indicate what the speaker is talking about, drawing attention to it. '은 [eun]' is used after words ending with a consonant, and '는 [neun]' is used after words ending with a vowel. These markers can also be used to contrast an idea, person, or thing with another.

examples.kr: 나는 학생입니다. 나는 한국어를 배우고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun haksaengimnida. Naneun hangugeoreul baeugo itsseumnida.
examples.en: I am a student. I am learning Korean.

examples.kr: 친구는 집에 있고, 저는 학교에 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Chinguneun jibe itgo, jeoneun hakgyoe itsseumnida.
examples.en: My friend is at home, and I am at school.

examples.kr: 오늘은 비가 오고, 내일은 맑습니다.
examples.romaji: Oneuleun biga ogo, naeireun malgsseumnida.
examples.en: It's raining today, but it will be clear tomorrow.

examples.kr: 이것은 책이고, 저것은 연필입니다.
examples.romaji: Igeoseun chaegigo, jeogeoseun yeonpilimnida.
examples.en: This is a book, and that is a pencil.

title: 을/를 [eul/reul] (Object markers)
short_explanation: Used to mark the object of a sentence in Korean.
long_explanation: '을/를 [eul/reul]' are object markers in Korean, indicating the object of an action in a sentence. They are used after a noun which is the object of the verb. They have no meaning on their own, but when attached to a noun, they signify that the noun is the object that the action of the verb is directed at.

examples.kr: 저는 매일 아침에 커피를 마셔요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeil achime keopireul masyeoyo.
examples.en: I drink coffee every morning.

examples.kr: 저는 이 책을 읽고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun i chaekeul ilgo isseoyo.
examples.en: I am reading this book.

examples.kr: 영화를 보러 가고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Yeongwareul boreo gago sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I want to go watch a movie.

examples.kr: 우리는 그들을 돕고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun geudeureul dobgo sip-eoyo.
examples.en: We want to help them.

title: 아니다 [anida] (To not be)
short_explanation: Used to express negation; 'to not be' or 'is not'.
long_explanation: '아니다 [anida]' is a negative verb used in Korean to indicate the non-existence or negation of something. It stands as the negative form of the verb '이다' ('to be'). '아니다' is used when the speaker wants to say a statement is incorrect or a certain condition or state is not present. This verb changes its form depending on formality and tense.

examples.kr: 제 책이 아니에요, 그것은 내 친구의 책입니다.
examples.romaji: Je chaeki anieyo, geugeoseun nae chinguui chaegimnida.
examples.en: That's not my book, it's my friend's book.

examples.kr: 우리는 너무 늦지 않았어요, 아직도 충분한 시간이 있어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun neomu neutji anasseoyo, ajikdo chungbunhan sigani isseoyo.
examples.en: We are not too late, we still have plenty of time.

examples.kr: 이 아름다운 공원은 자연이 아니에요, 인간이 만든 것입니다.
examples.romaji: I areumdaun gongwoneun jayeoni anieyo, ingani mandeun geosimnida.
examples.en: This beautiful park is not natural, it was made by humans.

examples.kr: 그는 나의 친구가 아니에요, 우리는 그저 동료입니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun naui chinguga anieyo, urineun geujeo donglyoimnida.
examples.en: He is not my friend, we are just colleagues.

title: 예요/이에요 [yeyo/ieyo] (Copula in the present tense)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that something or someone is a certain noun in a polite way (similar to 'is/am/are').
long_explanation: '예요/이에요' are polite present-tense forms of the Korean copula '이다,' used after nouns to show identification or classification. Choose '이에요' if the noun ends in a consonant, and '예요' if the noun ends in a vowel.
formation: Noun + 이에요 (if ending with a consonant) / 예요 (if ending with a vowel)

examples.kr: 저는 학생이에요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun haksaeng-ieyo.
examples.en: I am a student.

examples.kr: 이 사람은 제 친구예요.
examples.romaji: I sarameun je chingu-yeyo.
examples.en: This person is my friend.

examples.kr: 이것은 제 가방이에요.
examples.romaji: Igeoseun je gabang-ieyo.
examples.en: This is my bag.

examples.kr: 제 취미는 독서예요.
examples.romaji: Je chwimineun dokseo-yeyo.
examples.en: My hobby is reading.

title: 아요/어요/여요 [ayo/eoyo/yeoyo] (Verb ending in present tense)
short_explanation: Used as a polite verb ending in the present tense for verbs and adjectives.
long_explanation: '아요/어요/여요 [ayo/eoyo/yeoyo]' are endings attached to Korean verbs or adjectives to form the present tense in a polite but not overly formal style. If the stem’s final vowel is '아' or '오', use '아요'. For all other vowels, use '어요'. When a verb ends in '하다', it typically changes to '해요' (the most common contraction of '하여요').
formation: Verb/Adjective stem + 아요 (if stem ends in '아' or '오') / 어요 (if stem ends in other vowels) / 해요 (if stem ends with '하다')

examples.kr: 나는 한국어 공부하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun hangugeo gongbuhago isseoyo.
examples.en: I am studying Korean.

examples.kr: 우리 엄마는 맛있는 음식을 만들어요.
examples.romaji: Uri eommaneun masitneun eumsigeul mandeureoyo.
examples.en: My mom makes delicious food.

examples.kr: 선생님은 학생들에게 한국 문화에 대해 가르치고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnimeun haksaengdeulege hanguk munhwa-e daehae gareuchigo isseoyo.
examples.en: The teacher is teaching the students about Korean culture.

examples.kr: 그는 점심시간에 가끔 산책하러 가요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun jeomsimsigan-e gakkeum sancaekhareo gayo.
examples.en: He sometimes goes for a walk during lunchtime.

title: 고 [go] (And)
short_explanation: Used to link two or more clauses in a sentence; similar to 'and' in English.
long_explanation: '고 [go]' is a conjunction used in Korean to connect two or more clauses in a sentence, similar to the English conjunction 'and'. It can link actions, events, or states. In most cases, you remove '다' from the verb’s dictionary form and then add '고'.

examples.kr: 저는 오늘 학교에 가고, 공부하고, 친구들과 점심을 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun oneul hakgyoe gago, gongbuhago, chingudeulgwa jeomsimeul meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: Today, I went to school, studied, and ate lunch with my friends.

examples.kr: 그는 춤을 추고, 노래를 하고, 재미있게 놀았어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun chumeul chugo, noraereul hago, jaemiissge norasseoyo.
examples.en: He danced, sang, and had fun.

examples.kr: 나는 집에 가서 숙제를 하고 책을 읽었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun jibe gaseo sukjerul hago chaegeul ilgeosseoyo.
examples.en: I went home, did my homework, and read a book.

examples.kr: 우리는 점심을 먹고 영화를 보러 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun jeomsimeul meokgo yeonghwareul boreo gasseoyo.
examples.en: We ate lunch and went to watch a movie.

title: 하고 [hago] (And, with)
short_explanation: Used to express 'and' or 'with' when connecting nouns or activities shared with someone.
long_explanation: '하고 [hago]' is a conjunction used in Korean to link or associate two or more nouns (similar to 'and'), or to express doing something together with someone (similar to 'with'). It implies a joint action or connection between the listed nouns or people.

examples.kr: 저는 친구하고 영화를 보고 밥을 먹었어요, 그리고 집에 가서 숙제를 했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun chinguhago yeongwareul bogo babeul meogeosseoyo, geurigo jibe gaseo sukjereul haesseoyo.
examples.en: I watched a movie and ate with my friend, then went home and did my homework.

examples.kr: 이번 주말에는 가족하고 여행을 가기로 결정했어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumaleneun gajokhago yeohaengeul gagiro gyeoljeonghaesseoyo.
examples.en: I decided to go on a trip with my family this weekend.

examples.kr: 피터하고 메리는 함께 학교에 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Piteohago Merineun hamkke hakgyoe gasseoyo.
examples.en: Peter and Mary went to school together.

examples.kr: 나는 오늘 아빠하고 쇼핑하러 갈 계획이에요.
examples.romaji: Naneun oneul appahago syopinghareo gal gyehoegieyo.
examples.en: I plan to go shopping with my dad today.

title: (으)세요 [(eu)seyo] (Imperative form)
short_explanation: Used to give orders, instructions, or make polite requests.
long_explanation: '(으)세요 [(eu)seyo]' is an imperative form in Korean used to request or command someone to do something politely. It is considered an honorific form, so it is used when speaking to someone older or of higher status, or simply to be polite. Use '세요' if the verb stem ends with a vowel, and '으세요' if the verb stem ends with a consonant.
formation: Verb stem + 세요 (if stem’s final syllable is a vowel) / 으세요 (if stem’s final syllable is a consonant)

examples.kr: 조심해서 건너세요, 사고가 날 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Josimhaeseo geonneoseyo, sagoga nal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Cross carefully, there could be an accident.

examples.kr: 집에 돌아가서 먹어야 할 약을 먹으세요.
examples.romaji: Jibe doragaseo meog-eoya hal yag-eul meog-euseyo.
examples.en: Go home and take the medicine you need to take.

examples.kr: 이 메시지를 받으면 답장하세요.
examples.romaji: I mesijireul badeumyeon dapjanghaseyo.
examples.en: Reply once you receive this message.

examples.kr: 오늘 저녁에 만나야 할 사람들에게 미리 전화하세요.
examples.romaji: Oneul jeonyeog-e manna-ya hal saramdeuregge miri jeonhwahaseyo.
examples.en: Call the people you have to meet this evening in advance.

title: (으)ㄹ 수 있다 [(eu)l su itda] (Can do)
short_explanation: This form indicates the potential ability or possibility to perform something.
long_explanation: '(으)ㄹ 수 있다' is a fundamental Korean grammar point that conveys the potential ability to do something. It works like 'can' in English. It indicates that an action is possible or that an event may occur, and also implies that the speaker (or subject) either has the ability or the permission to do the action described by the preceding verb.

examples.kr: 그녀는 한국어를 매우 빠르게 배울 수 있으므로, 한 달 만에 토픽 시험을 볼 수 있을 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hangugeoreul maeu bbareuge baeul su isseumuro, han dal mane topik siheomeul bol su isseul geosimnida.
examples.en: Because she can learn Korean very quickly, she will be able to take the TOPIK test in a month.

examples.kr: 집이 가까우니까, 열심히 공부하면 한 달 안에 한국어를 유창하게 할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jibi gakkaunikka, yeolsimhi gongbuhamyeon han dal ane hangugeoreul yuchanghage hal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Since your house is nearby, if you study hard, you can become fluent in Korean within a month.

examples.kr: 그것에 대해 많이 알고 있어서, 그에 대한 모든 질문에 답할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geugeote daehae manhi algo isseoseo, geue daehan modeun jilmune daphal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Since I know a lot about it, I can answer all questions related to it.

examples.kr: 당신이 이해하기 어렵다면, 조금 더 천천히 말할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Dangsini ihaehagi eoryeopdamyeon, jogeum deo cheoncheonhi malhal su isseoyo.
examples.en: If you find it hard to understand, I can speak a bit more slowly.

title: (으)려고 [(eu)ryeogo] (Intention to do)
short_explanation: Used to express the speaker's intention or plan to do something.
long_explanation: The '(으)려고' form is used in Korean to express intention or a plan to do something. It can be translated roughly as 'in order to,' 'intend to,' or 'plan to.' You can use it when talking about your own intentions or other people's intentions that you know of. It often implies a future action or purposeful activity.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 배우려고 한국에 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul baeuryeogo hanguk-e wasseoyo.
examples.en: I came to Korea to learn Korean.

examples.kr: 누나는 살을 빼려고 운동하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Nunaneun sal-eul ppaeryeogo undonghago isseoyo.
examples.en: My older sister is exercising in order to lose weight.

examples.kr: 학생들은 시험에 통과하려고 열심히 공부하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Haksaengdeureun siheome tonggwaharyeogo yeolsimhi gongbuhago isseoyo.
examples.en: The students are studying hard in order to pass the exam.

examples.kr: 아빠는 아이들에게 좋은 생활을 제공하려고 매일 일해요.
examples.romaji: Appaneun aideurege joeun saenghwareul jegongharyeogo maeil ilhaeyo.
examples.en: Father works every day to provide a good life for his children.

title: (으)ㄴ/는다 [(eu)n/neunda] (Informal statement endings)
short_explanation: Used in informal or plain-style statements to make assertions or descriptions.
long_explanation: '(으)ㄴ/는다' are plain-style (informal) statement endings in Korean. They often appear in written narratives, diaries, or casual speech among peers. If the verb stem ends in a vowel, use 'ㄴ다.' If the verb stem ends in a consonant, use '는다.'
formation: Verb stem + ㄴ다 (if stem ends with a vowel), Verb stem + 는다 (if stem ends with a consonant)

examples.kr: 나는 오늘 자정에 집에 돌아온다.
examples.romaji: Naneun oneul jajeong-e jibe doraonda.
examples.en: I’m coming back home at midnight today.

examples.kr: 그는 스페인어를 잘 한다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun seupeineoreul jal handa.
examples.en: He speaks Spanish well.

examples.kr: 이 커피는 너무 진하다.
examples.romaji: I keopineun neomu jinhada.
examples.en: This coffee is too strong.

examples.kr: 우리는 내일 공원에 가서 피크닉을 한다.
examples.romaji: Urineun naeil gongwone gaseo piknikeul handa.
examples.en: We’ll go to the park tomorrow and have a picnic.

title: 도 [do] (Too, also)
short_explanation: Used to indicate addition, similarity, or emphasis ('too', 'also', 'even').
long_explanation: '도' is a particle that means 'too,' 'also,' or 'even' depending on context. It can be attached to nouns, pronouns, or other particles, indicating that the mentioned item is in addition to or shares the same property/action as something else.

examples.kr: 나는 커피를 좋아하고, 친구도 커피를 좋아해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun keopireul joahago, chingudo keopireul joahaeyo.
examples.en: I like coffee, and my friend also likes coffee.

examples.kr: 철수는 축구를 할 수 있어요, 그리고 민희도 축구를 할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Cheolsuneun chukgureul hal su isseoyo, geurigo Minheedo chukgureul hal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Cheolsu can play soccer, and Minhee can also play soccer.

examples.kr: 이 영화는 재미있어요, 그래서 많은 사람들이 지금까지도 계속 이 영화를 봐요.
examples.romaji: I yeonghwaneun jaemiisseoyo, geuraeseo maneun saramdeuri jigeumkkajido gyesok i yeonghwareul bwayo.
examples.en: This movie is fun, so many people still continue to watch it.

examples.kr: 이번 시험은 어려웠어요, 그래서 나도, 친구들도 잘 못 봤어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon siheomeun eoryeowosseoyo, geuraeseo nado, chingudeuldo jal mot bwasseoyo.
examples.en: This test was difficult, so both I and my friends didn’t do well.

title: 만 [man] (Only)
short_explanation: Used to express the concept of 'only' or 'just' in Korean.
long_explanation: '만' is a particle that indicates exclusivity. The noun (or pronoun) before '만' is the only or the sole subject/object in the context, emphasizing that no other people, items, or circumstances apply.

examples.kr: 저는 커피만 마십니다. 차는 마시지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun keopiman masimnida. Chaneun masiji anhayo.
examples.en: I only drink coffee. I don’t drink tea.

examples.kr: 제 친구는 한국어만 할 줄 알아요. 다른 언어는 전혀 못 해요.
examples.romaji: Je chinguneun hangugeoman hal jul arayo. Dareun eoneoneun jeonhyeo mot haeyo.
examples.en: My friend can only speak Korean. He can’t speak any other language at all.

examples.kr: 저는 데이트를 할 때 영화만 보러 가요. 다른 활동은 잘 안 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun deiteureul hal ttae yeonghwaman boreo gayo. Dareun hwaldongeun jal an haeyo.
examples.en: When I go on dates, I only go to the movies. I don’t really do other activities.

examples.kr: 이번 달에는 돈을 아끼려고 교통비만 썼어요. 다른 데에는 안 썼어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon dal-eneun doneul akkiryeogo gyotongbiman sseosseoyo. Dareun de-e-neun an sseosseoyo.
examples.en: This month, to save money, I only spent on transportation. I didn’t spend on anything else.

title: 와/과 [wa/gwa] (And, with – for nouns)
short_explanation: Used to link two nouns in a similar way to 'and' or 'with' in English.
long_explanation: '와/과' is a particle used to connect two nouns in Korean. If the final character of the first noun is a vowel, '와' is used. If it is a consonant, '과' is used. It can mean 'and' or 'with,' depending on context.
formation: Noun (ending in vowel) + 와 + Noun / Noun (ending in consonant) + 과 + Noun

examples.kr: 나는 공원에서 강아지와 뛰어놀았어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun gongwon-eseo gangajiwa ttwieonorasseoyo.
examples.en: I played with a puppy in the park.

examples.kr: 나는 빵과 커피를 함께 먹는 것을 좋아해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun ppang-gwa keopireul hamkke meokneun geoseul joahaeyo.
examples.en: I like eating bread and coffee together.

examples.kr: 친구와 연필과 함께 공부했어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguwa yeonpilgwa hamkke gongbuhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I studied with a friend and a pencil.

examples.kr: 나는 내 가족과 여행을 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun nae gajok-gwa yeohaengeul gasseoyo.
examples.en: I went on a trip with my family.

title: 부터 [buteo] (From)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the starting point in time or space; 'from'.
long_explanation: '부터' indicates the starting point of an action, period, or range in Korean. It translates to 'from' in English. It is frequently used with time expressions (e.g., '오늘부터' = 'from today').

examples.kr: 나는 오늘부터 다이어트를 시작할 거예요, 그래서 단 것은 더 이상 먹지 않을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Naneun oneulbuteo daieoteureul sijakhal geoyeyo, geuraeseo dan geoseun deo isang meokji anheul geoyeyo.
examples.en: I’ll start dieting from today, so I won’t eat sweets anymore.

examples.kr: 어린이부터 어른까지 모두 이 영화를 즐길 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Eorinibuteo eoreunkkaji modu i yeonghwareul jeulgil su isseoyo.
examples.en: Everyone from children to adults can enjoy this movie.

examples.kr: 우리는 내일부터 다시 일을 시작해야 해요, 그러니 오늘은 푹 쉬세요.
examples.romaji: Urineun naeilbuteo dashi ireul sijakhaya haeyo, geureoni oneureun puk swiseyo.
examples.en: We have to start work again from tomorrow, so get plenty of rest today.

examples.kr: 나는 작년 여름부터 한국어를 공부하기 시작했어요, 그래서 이제 조금은 할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun jaknyeon yeoreumbuteo hangugeoreul gongbuhagi sijakhaesseoyo, geuraeseo ije jogeumeun hal su isseoyo.
examples.en: I started studying Korean from last summer, so now I can speak a little.

title: 까지 [kkaji] (Until, up to)
short_explanation: Used to mark the endpoint or limit in time, space, amount, or degree.
long_explanation: '까지' is a postposition that indicates the limit or endpoint of a range in Korean, similar to 'until' or 'up to' in English. It is widely used with time expressions (e.g., '내일까지' = 'until tomorrow'), as well as physical locations or quantities.

examples.kr: 첫 번째 학기는 총 여섯 달 동안이에요. 즉, 1월부터 6월까지입니다.
examples.romaji: Cheot beonjjae hakgineun chong yeoseot dal dongan-ieyo. Jik, irwolbuteo yugwolkkajiimnida.
examples.en: The first semester lasts for six months, that is, from January until June.

examples.kr: 저는 매일 아침 일찍 일어나서 밤 10시까지 일합니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeil achim iljjik ireonaseo bam yeolsotsikkaji ilhamnida.
examples.en: I wake up early every morning and work until 10 p.m.

examples.kr: 오늘은 돈이 오천 원까지밖에 없어서 저녁을 거르게 됐어요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun doni ocheon won-kkajibakke eopseoseo jeonyeogeul georeuge dwaesseoyo.
examples.en: I only had up to 5,000 won today, so I ended up skipping dinner.

examples.kr: 지금까지 한 일을 포함해서 모든 내용을 보고서에 적어주세요.
examples.romaji: Jigeumkkaji han ireul pohamhaeseo modeun naeyongeul bogoseoe jeogeojuseyo.
examples.en: Please include everything you’ve done up until now in the report.

title: 아/어/여서 [a/eo/yeoseo] (Because, since)
short_explanation: Used to denote a reason or cause, similar to 'because' or 'since' in English.
long_explanation: '아/어/여서' is a conjunctive ending that indicates the reason or cause of the following clause. It is attached directly to the verb or adjective stem to show why something happened.

examples.kr: 밖에 비가 와서 감기에 걸렸어요, 그래서 학교에 못 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Bakke biga waseo gamgie geollyeosseoyo, geuraeseo hakgyoe mot gasseoyo.
examples.en: Because it rained outside, I caught a cold, so I couldn’t go to school.

examples.kr: 그는 배가 고파서 간식을 준비했어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun baega gopaseo gansigeul junbihaesseoyo.
examples.en: Because he was hungry, I prepared a snack.

examples.kr: 영화를 보느라고 시간이 없어서 숙제를 전혀 못 했어요.
examples.romaji: Yeonghwareul boneurago sigani eopseoseo sukjereul jeonhyeo mot haesseoyo.
examples.en: Since I was watching a movie and didn’t have time, I couldn’t do any homework.

examples.kr: 수업이 어렵다고 생각해서 매일 열심히 공부하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Sueobi eoryeopdago saenggakhaeseo maeil yeolsimhi gongbuhago isseoyo.
examples.en: Because I think the class is difficult, I study hard every day.

title: (으)면 [(eu)myeon] (If, when)
short_explanation: This is generally used to express 'if' or 'when'. It's employed to present conditions and the possible consequences of those conditions.
long_explanation: (으)면 [(eu)myeon] is a conditional ending in Korean attached to a verb or adjective stem. It can mean 'if', 'when', or 'in case'. This grammar point sets up a condition in the (으)면-clause, and the main clause explains the result or consequence that follows from that condition.

examples.kr: 시간이 있으면, 저는 매일 한국어를 공부하고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Sigani isseumyeon, jeoneun maeil hangugeoreul gongbuhago sip-eoyo.
examples.en: If I have time, I want to study Korean every day.

examples.kr: 날씨가 좋으면 나는 산에 등산하러 갈 거야.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga joheumyeon naneun sane deungsanhareo gal geoya.
examples.en: If the weather is good, I will go hiking in the mountains.

examples.kr: 피곤하면 일찍 자는 것이 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Pigonhamyeon iljjik janeun geosi joayo.
examples.en: If you are tired, it's good to sleep early.

examples.kr: 이 테스트를 통과하면, 나는 학교에 입학할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: I teseuteureul tonggwahamyeon, naneun hakgyoe ibhakhal su isseoyo.
examples.en: If I pass this test, I can enter school.

title: 너무 [neomu] (Too, very)
short_explanation: Used to express a high degree or extent; 'too', 'very'.
long_explanation: '너무 [neomu]' is an adverb in Korean that emphasizes a strong degree or intensity of something. It can mean 'too (much)' or 'very', highlighting that something goes beyond the norm or is extremely so. It typically modifies verbs or adjectives.

examples.kr: 이것은 너무 맛있어서 제가 모두 먹어버렸어요. 다른 사람들을 위해 남겨두지 못했습니다.
examples.romaji: Igeoseun neomu masisseoseo jega modu meogeobeoryeosseoyo. Dareun saramdeureul wihae namgyeoduji moshaessseumnida.
examples.en: This was so delicious that I ate it all; I couldn't leave any for others.

examples.kr: 이 영화는 너무 재미있어서 저는 이미 세 번이나 봤어요. 아직도 다시 보고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: I yeonghwaneun neomu jaemiisseoseo jeoneun imi se beonina bwasseoyo. Ajikdo dasi bogo sip-eoyo.
examples.en: This movie is so fun that I've already watched it three times, and I still want to watch it again.

examples.kr: 그녀가 너무 예뻐서 저는 매일 그녀를 볼 수 있으면 좋겠어요, 하지만 그녀는 저를 몰라요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga neomu yeppeoseo jeoneun maeil geunyeoreul bol su isseumyeon johgess-eoyo, hajiman geunyeoneun jeoreul mollayo.
examples.en: She is so pretty that I wish I could see her every day, but she doesn't know me.

examples.kr: 피자가 너무 맛있어서 저는 매주 먹어요, 하지만 이제부터는 조금 줄여야 될 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Pijaga neomu masisseoseo jeoneun maeju meogeoyo, hajiman ijebuteoneun jogeum julyeoya doel geot gatayo.
examples.en: The pizza is so delicious that I eat it every week, but I think I should cut down a bit from now on.

title: 많이 [manhi] (A lot)
short_explanation: Used to express a large quantity, frequency, or degree; 'a lot', 'many', 'much'.
long_explanation: '많이 [manhi]' is an adverb that indicates a large amount, frequency, or degree. It can be used with verbs, adjectives, and sometimes nouns (in certain constructions). It's similar to 'a lot' or 'much' in English.

examples.kr: 저는 친구가 많이 필요해서 항상 사람들을 만나러 다니는 편이에요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun chinguga manhi piryohaeseo hangsang saramdeureul mannareo danineun pyeon-ieyo.
examples.en: I need a lot of friends, so I tend to go out to meet people.

examples.kr: 그 영화를 봤어요? 저는 많이 웃었어요!
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwareul bwasseoyo? Jeoneun manhi useosseoyo!
examples.en: Have you seen that movie? I laughed a lot!

examples.kr: 요즘 일이 많이 바빠서 휴가를 가고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Yojeum ili manhi bappaseo hyugareul gago sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I've been very busy at work these days, so I want to go on vacation.

examples.kr: 그녀는 항상 많이 운동해서 건강해 보이세요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hangsang manhi undonghaeseo geonganghae boiseyo.
examples.en: She always exercises a lot, so she looks healthy.

title: 조금 [jogeum] (A little)
short_explanation: Used to indicate a small amount or degree; 'a little', 'a bit'.
long_explanation: '조금 [jogeum]' is an adverb that describes a small or modest amount or degree. It's similar to 'a little' or 'a bit' in English. It can be used with verbs to reduce intensity, or with adjectives to lessen the strength of a description.

examples.kr: 기분이 안 좋아요. 조금 쉴 필요가 있어요.
examples.romaji: Gibuni an joayo. Jogeum swil piryoga isseoyo.
examples.en: I'm not feeling well. I need to rest a bit.

examples.kr: 방이 조금 어둡습니다. 불을 켜주세요.
examples.romaji: Bangi jogeum eodubseumnida. Bureul kyeojuseyo.
examples.en: The room is a bit dark. Please turn on the light.

examples.kr: 짐이 너무 무거워요. 조금 줄여야 할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Jim-i neomu mugeowoyo. Jogeum julyeoya hal geot gatayo.
examples.en: The luggage is too heavy. I think I need to cut it down a bit.

examples.kr: 그녀는 한국어를 조금 알아요, 그래서 간단한 대화는 가능해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hangugeoreul jogeum arayo, geuraeseo gandanhan daehwaneun ganeunghaeyo.
examples.en: She knows a little Korean, so simple conversation is possible.

title: 다 [da] (All, entirely)
short_explanation: Used to express the entirety or completeness of an action or state.
long_explanation: '다 [da]' here functions as an adverb meaning 'all' or 'entirely.' It emphasizes the complete or total aspect of an action or state. In other words, everything is done or used up, or everyone/everything is involved.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 공부하는 책을 다 읽었어요, 그래서 이제 뭐 읽을지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul gongbuhaneun chaekeul da ilgeosseoyo, geuraeseo ije mwo ilgeulji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I read all the books about studying Korean, so now I don't know what else to read.

examples.kr: 우리 영화를 다 보고 나서야 집에 돌아갔어요.
examples.romaji: Uri yeonghwareul da bogo nasaya jibe doragasseoyo.
examples.en: We only went home after watching the entire movie.

examples.kr: 그녀는 한국에 오면서 한국 음식을 다 좋아한다고 말했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hanguke omyeonseo hanguk eumsigeul da joahandago malhaesseoyo.
examples.en: She said she likes all Korean food after coming to Korea.

examples.kr: 이번 주 식료품을 다 사 왔어요, 그래서 주방에는 빈 칸이 하나도 없어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon ju sigryopumeul da sa wasseoyo, geuraeseo jubang-eneun bin kani hanado eopseoyo.
examples.en: I bought all the groceries this week, so there's not a single empty space in the kitchen.

title: (으)ㄴ/는데 [(eu)n/neunde] (But, however)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast or contradiction; 'but', 'however'.
long_explanation: '(으)ㄴ/는데' is used to express a contrast or introduce background information. It's similar to 'but' or 'however' in English, but can also be used for transitions or providing context. For verbs in the present tense, use '는데', while for descriptive verbs (adjectives), the form can be '(으)ㄴ데'.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 좋은데, 저는 집에만 있고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga joheunde, jeoneun jibeman itgo sip-eoyo.
examples.en: The weather is nice today, but I just want to stay home.

examples.kr: 그는 매우 친절한데, 가끔은 너무 솔직해서 상처를 줄 때가 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun maeu chinjeolhande, gakkeumeun neomu soljikhaeseo sangcheoreul jul ttaega isseoyo.
examples.en: He's very kind, but sometimes he's so honest that he can hurt people.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어 공부를 오래 했는데도 불구하고 아직 많이 부족해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeo gongbureul orae haetneundedo bulguhago ajik manhi bujokhaeyo.
examples.en: I've studied Korean for a long time, but I'm still lacking a lot.

examples.kr: 이 옷은 예쁜데, 제 스타일이 아니에요.
examples.romaji: I oseun yeppeunde, je seutairi anieyo.
examples.en: This outfit is pretty, but it's not my style.

title: 아/어야 해요 [a/eoya haeyo] (Have to do)
short_explanation: Used to express necessity or obligation; 'have to', 'must', 'should'.
long_explanation: '아/어야 해요' is used when you must or need to do something. It conveys a strong sense of requirement or obligation, similar to 'have to' or 'must' in English. The exact form (아, 어, or 여) depends on the final vowel of the verb stem.

examples.kr: 이렇게 많은 공부가 있으니까, 우리는 빨리 시작해야 해요. 그렇지 않으면 시간이 부족해서 모든 것을 끝낼 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Ireohke manheun gongbuga issnikka, urineun ppalli sijakhaeya haeyo. Geureohji anheumyeon sigani bujokhaeseo modeun geoseul kkeutnael su eopseoyo.
examples.en: Since there's so much to study, we have to start quickly. Otherwise, we'll run out of time and won't be able to finish everything.

examples.kr: 주말에 시험이 있으므로 저는 지금부터 준비해야 해요. 그만큼 공부하지 않으면 시험에 실패할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jumare siheomi isseumuro jeoneun jigeumbuteo junbihaeya haeyo. Geumankeum gongbuhaji anheumyeon siheome silpaehal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Because I have an exam this weekend, I have to prepare from now on. If I don't study enough, I might fail.

examples.kr: 내일 회사에 아침 일찍 가야 해요. 중요한 회의가 있어서 꼭 참석해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Naeil hoesa-e achim iljjik gaya haeyo. Jungyohan hoeuiga isseoseo kkok chamseokhaeya haeyo.
examples.en: I have to go to the office early tomorrow morning. There's an important meeting I must attend.

examples.kr: 여름에는 SPF가 중요하니까, 밖에 나가기 전에 자외선 차단제를 발라야 해요. 안 그러면 피부가 상할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Yeoreumeneun SPFga jungyohanikka, bakke nagagi jeone jaweseon chadanje-reul ballaya haeyo. An geureomyeon pibuga sanghal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Since SPF is important in the summer, you have to apply sunscreen before going out. Otherwise, your skin might get damaged.

title: 안 [an] (Negation before verb/adjective)
short_explanation: Used to negate verbs and adjectives in Korean; equivalent to 'not'.
long_explanation: '안 [an]' is an adverb that goes in front of a verb or adjective to negate it, similar to 'not' in English. It completely flips the meaning of the sentence, stating that the action or state does not happen or does not apply.

examples.kr: 저는 아직 안 자요. 아직 일이 남았어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ajik an jayo. Ajik iri namasseoyo.
examples.en: I haven't slept yet. There's still work left.

examples.kr: 내 친구는 연어를 안 먹어요. 그녀는 생선을 좋아하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Nae chinguneun yeoneoreul an meogeoyo. Geunyeoneun saengseoneul joahaji anhayo.
examples.en: My friend doesn't eat salmon. She doesn't like fish.

examples.kr: 너는 그 영화를 안 봤어요? 정말 재미있어요, 꼭 봐야 해요.
examples.romaji: Neoneun geu yeonghwareul an bwasseoyo? Jeongmal jaemiisseoyo, kkok bwaya haeyo.
examples.en: You haven't seen that movie? It's really good; you must watch it.

examples.kr: 제가 그 사람을 진짜 안 좋아해요, 그는 항상 거짓말을 하니까요.
examples.romaji: Jega geu sarameul jinjja an joahaeyo, geuneun hangsang geojitmareul hanikkayo.
examples.en: I really don't like that person because he always tells lies.

title: 못 [mot] (Can't, not able to)
short_explanation: Used to express inability or impossibility; 'can't', 'not able to'.
long_explanation: '못 [mot]' is a Korean adverb used to indicate an inability or impossibility to do something. This can be a physical inability, a matter of circumstance, or a lack of permission. It corresponds to 'can't' or 'not able to' in English and is placed directly before the verb.

examples.kr: 오늘은 너무 피곤해서 저는 일찍 잠을 못 잤어요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun neomu pigonhaeseo jeoneun iljjik jameul mot jasseoyo.
examples.en: Today I was so tired that I couldn't go to sleep early.

examples.kr: 그녀는 많이 걱정하고 스트레스를 받아서 밥을 못 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun manhi geokjeonghago seuteureseureul badaseo babeul mot meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: She was so worried and stressed that she couldn't eat.

examples.kr: 비가 너무 많이 와서 우리는 놀이공원에 갈 수가 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Biga neomu mani waseo urineun noligongweone gal suga eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: Because it rained so much, we couldn't go to the amusement park.

examples.kr: 저는 너무 늦게 와서 회의에 참석을 못 했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun neomu neujge waseo hoeuie chamseogeul mot haesseoyo.
examples.en: I arrived too late, so I couldn't attend the meeting.

title: 아/어/여 보다 [a/eo/yeo boda] (Try doing)
short_explanation: Expresses an attempt or an experience of doing something; 'try doing'.
long_explanation: '아/어/여 보다' is used in Korean to show that one attempts or experiences a certain action. It is attached to an action verb stem, while the final verb '보다' takes the tense. It can also be used to describe having done something at least once in the past (an experience).

examples.kr: 이 문제를 어떻게 해결할지 모르겠으면, 제 방식대로 한 번 해보아요.
examples.romaji: I munjereul eotteoke haegyeolhalji moreugesseumyeon, je bangsikdaero han beon haeboayo.
examples.en: If you don't know how to solve this problem, you should try doing it my way.

examples.kr: 김치를 만들어 본 적이 없다면, 한 번 시도해 보세요. 정말 쉽고 재미있어요.
examples.romaji: Kimchireul mandeureo bon jeogi eopdamyeon, han beon sidohae boseyo. Jeongmal swipgo jaemi isseoyo.
examples.en: If you've never tried making kimchi, give it a go. It's really easy and fun.

examples.kr: 예전에 한국어를 배워 보았지만, 전혀 기억이 안 나요.
examples.romaji: Yejeone hangugeoreul baewo boassjiman, jeonhyeo gieogi an nayo.
examples.en: I've tried to learn Korean before, but I don't remember anything.

examples.kr: 이 방법으로 공부해 보았는데, 결과가 아주 좋았어요.
examples.romaji: I bangbeobeuro gongbuhae boassneunde, gyeolgwa ga aju joasseoyo.
examples.en: I tried studying this way, and the results were very good.

title: 지금 [jigeum] (Now)
short_explanation: Used to refer to 'now' or the 'current moment'.
long_explanation: '지금 [jigeum]' means 'now' or 'at this moment' in English. It indicates that the speaker is referring to the immediate present. It can be used before verbs or at the start of a sentence to emphasize current time.
formation: 지금 (often used at the start of a clause or right before the verb)

examples.kr: 지금 학교에 가야 해요. 수업이 곧 시작될 거예요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum hakgyoe gaya haeyo. Sueopi got sijakdoel geoyeyo.
examples.en: I have to go to school now. The class is about to start.

examples.kr: 지금 비가 오고 있어요. 우산을 가져가는 게 좋을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum biga ogo isseoyo. Usaneul gajyeoganeun ge joh-eul geot gatayo.
examples.en: It's raining now. It would be a good idea to take an umbrella.

examples.kr: 지금 숙제를 하고 있어요. 나중에 전화할게요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum sukjereul hago isseoyo. Najunge jeonhwahalgeyo.
examples.en: I'm doing my homework now. I'll call you later.

examples.kr: 지금 저희 집에 오시면 식사를 같이 할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum jeoheui jib-e osimyeon siksareul gachi hal su isseoyo.
examples.en: If you come to my house now, we can have a meal together.

title: 이미 [imi] (Already)
short_explanation: Used to express an action that has already taken place.
long_explanation: '이미 [imi]' is an adverb meaning 'already'. It is used when an action or situation has occurred before the current moment or earlier than expected. It emphasizes that something is not new or pending, but has taken place beforehand.

examples.kr: 너는 이미 그 영화를 보았기 때문에, 또 보러 가는 게 무슨 의미가 있나요?
examples.romaji: Neoneun imi geu yeonghwareul boassgi ttaemune, tto boreo ganeun ge museun uimiga innayo?
examples.en: Since you've already seen that movie, what's the point of going again?

examples.kr: 저는 이미 저녁을 먹었으니, 당신은 혼자 저녁을 드세요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun imi jeonyeogeul meogeosseuni, dangsineun honja jeonyeogeul deuseyo.
examples.en: I have already eaten dinner, so you should have dinner on your own.

examples.kr: 작년에 이미 그 회사 주식을 팔았기 때문에, 이제는 아무런 손실도 없어요.
examples.romaji: Jaknyeone imi geu hoesa jusigeul palassgi ttaemune, ijeneun amureon sonsildo eopseoyo.
examples.en: Since I already sold that company's stock last year, there's no loss now.

examples.kr: 이곳에 왔을 때, 해는 이미 떠 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Igose wasseul ttae, haeneun imi tteo isseosseoyo.
examples.en: When I came here, the sun had already risen.

title: 아직 [ajik] (Yet, still)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that a condition or situation persists; 'yet', 'still'.
long_explanation: '아직 [ajik]' shows that an action or state is not finished or has not changed up to now. It can be translated as 'still' or 'yet' in English, depending on the context. It often appears in negative contexts (아직 안 했다) but can also be used more neutrally (아직 하고 있다).

examples.kr: 아직 저는 한국어를 완벽하게 이해하지 못해요. 계속 연습이 필요해요.
examples.romaji: Ajik jeoneun hangugeoreul wanbyeokhage ihaehaji mothaeyo. Gyesok yeonseub-i piryohaeyo.
examples.en: I still cannot fully understand Korean. I need to keep practicing.

examples.kr: 결정할 수 있어도, 아직 그 문제에 대해 생각 중이에요.
examples.romaji: Gyeoljeonghal su iss-eodo, ajik geu munjee daehae saenggak jung-ieyo.
examples.en: Even though I can decide, I'm still thinking about that issue.

examples.kr: 아직 그 영화를 보지 않았어요. 주말에 볼 예정이에요.
examples.romaji: Ajik geu yeonghwareul boji anasseoyo. Jumal-e bol yejeong-ieyo.
examples.en: I haven't watched that movie yet. I plan to see it this weekend.

examples.kr: 아직 점심을 먹지 않았어요. 배가 너무 고프네요.
examples.romaji: Ajik jeomsimeul meokji anasseoyo. Baega neomu gopeuneyo.
examples.en: I haven't had lunch yet. I'm really hungry.

title: 때 [ttae] (When, time)
short_explanation: Used to indicate a specific time or moment; 'when', 'at the time'.
long_explanation: '때 [ttae]' is a noun meaning 'time' or 'moment.' It is commonly attached to a verb stem (or sometimes a noun + 적 or similar forms) to indicate 'when' something happened or will happen. It's very versatile and appears in expressions like '어릴 때' (when I was young) or '시간이 없을 때' (when there is no time).

examples.kr: 저는 어릴 때부터 한국어를 배우고 싶어했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun eoril ttaebuteo hangugeoreul baeugo sipeohaesseoyo.
examples.en: I have wanted to learn Korean since I was young.

examples.kr: 그 여자가 웃을 때, 저는 정말 행복해요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeojaga useul ttae, jeoneun jeongmal haengbokhaeyo.
examples.en: When she smiles, I feel truly happy.

examples.kr: 첫 만남 때, 그를 절대 잊지 못할 거예요.
examples.romaji: Cheot mannam ttae, geureul jeoldae itji mothal geoyeyo.
examples.en: When we first met, I knew I'd never forget him.

examples.kr: 이번 주말에 여행을 가고 싶은데, 시간이 없을 때 어떻게 해야 할까요?
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumare yeohaengeul gago sip-eunde, sigani eopseul ttae eotteoke haeya halkkayo?
examples.en: I want to travel this weekend, but what should I do when there's no time?

title: (으)려고 하다 [(eu)ryeogo hada] (Intend to do)
short_explanation: Used to express the intention or plan to do something.
long_explanation: '(으)려고 하다' is used to say that someone intends or plans to do something in the future. The verb stem is followed by (으)려고, then '하다' is conjugated to show tense or politeness level. It often implies a near-future plan or deliberate intention.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 더 잘하기 위해 노력하려고 합니다. 연습을 많이 해서 실력을 키우려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul deo jalhagi wihae noryeokharyeogo hamnida. Yeonseubeul manhi haeseo sillyeogeul kiuryeogo haeyo.
examples.en: I intend to work hard to improve my Korean. I plan to practice a lot to build my skills.

examples.kr: 내일 비가 오려고 하니 우산을 챙기려고 해요. 감기를 예방하려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Naeil biga oryeogo hani usaneul chaenggiryego haeyo. Gamgireul yebangharyeogo hamnida.
examples.en: Since it looks like it will rain tomorrow, I intend to take an umbrella. I'm trying to prevent catching a cold.

examples.kr: 친구와 함께 여행을 가려고 해요. 같이 좋은 추억을 만들려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Chinguwa hamkke yeohaengeul garyeogo haeyo. Gachi joeun chu-eokeul mandeulryeogo hamnida.
examples.en: I'm planning to go on a trip with my friend. I want to make good memories together.

examples.kr: 그녀는 다음 달에 결혼 준비를 하려고 해요. 모든 것을 완벽하게 만들려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun daeum dale gyeolhon junbireul haryeogo haeyo. Modeun geoseul wanbyeokhage mandeulryeogo haeyo.
examples.en: She plans to prepare for her wedding next month. She wants everything to be perfect.

title: 처럼 [cheoreom] (Like, as)
short_explanation: Used to express similarity or comparison, like 'like' or 'as' in English.
long_explanation: '처럼 [cheoreom]' is a Korean particle that expresses similarity to or comparison with the preceding noun. It can be read as 'like (something)' or 'as (something).' It often appears in similes or metaphors, but can also be used literally.

examples.kr: 그는 사자처럼 강해 보였지만, 실제로는 그렇게 강하진 않아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun sajacheoreom ganghae boyeotjiman, siljero-neun geureohge ganghajin anhayo.
examples.en: He seemed strong like a lion, but in reality, he's not that strong.

examples.kr: 우리 친구는 항상 별처럼 빛나요. 모두에게 사랑받는 사람입니다.
examples.romaji: Uri chinguneun hangsang byeolcheoreom bitnayo. Modeuege sarangbatneun saramimnida.
examples.en: Our friend always shines like a star. She is someone everyone loves.

examples.kr: 그녀는 나비처럼 춤을 춰요. 정말 아름답고 우아해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun nabicheoreom chumeul chwoyo. Jeongmal areumdapgo uahaeyo.
examples.en: She dances like a butterfly. It's really beautiful and graceful.

examples.kr: 그는 독수리처럼 높이 날아갔어요. 비행이 아주 인상적이었어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun doksuricheoreom nopi naragasseoyo. Bihaengi aju insangjeogieosseoyo.
examples.en: He flew high like an eagle. His flight was very impressive.

title: 같이 [gachi] (Together)
short_explanation: Used to express 'together' or 'along with'.
long_explanation: '같이 [gachi]' is an adverb meaning 'together'. It often follows a noun (e.g., 엄마랑 같이) or appears before the verb. It emphasizes doing something in each other's company or jointly with someone else.

examples.kr: 제 친구와 같이 영화를 보러 갔어요. 정말 재미있었어요!
examples.romaji: Je chinguwa gachi yeonghwareul boreo gasseoyo. Jeongmal jaemiisseosseoyo!
examples.en: I went to watch a movie together with my friend. It was really fun!

examples.kr: 내일은 우리 모두 같이 공원에 가서 피크닉을 하기로 했어요.
examples.romaji: Naeireun uri modu gachi gongwone gaseo piknikeul hagiro haesseoyo.
examples.en: We decided that tomorrow we'll all go to the park together for a picnic.

examples.kr: 엄마와 같이 요리하면 항상 더 맛있는 음식을 만들 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Eommawa gachi yorihamyeon hangsang deo masinneun eumsigeul mandeul su isseoyo.
examples.en: If I cook with my mom, I can always make more delicious food.

examples.kr: 과외 선생님과 같이 공부하면 많은 도움이 돼요.
examples.romaji: Gwaoe seonsaengnimgwa gachi gongbuhamyeon manheun doumi dwaeyo.
examples.en: Studying with a private tutor is very helpful.

title: (이)랑 [(i)rang] (With)
short_explanation: Used to express 'with' or 'and' when referring to being together or doing something together.
long_explanation: '(이)랑 [(i)rang]' is a conjunctive particle used in Korean to denote the concept of 'with' or 'and'. It connotes a sense of togetherness, indicating that the speaker is together with someone or doing something jointly. If the noun ends with a vowel, use '랑 [rang]'; if it ends with a consonant, use '이랑 [irang]'.
formation: Vowel-ending noun + 랑, Consonant-ending noun + 이랑

examples.kr: 제가 친구랑 영화를 봤어요, 그 영화는 재미있었어요.
examples.romaji: Jega chingurang yeonghwaleul bwasseoyo, geu yeonghwaneun jaemiisseosseoyo.
examples.en: I watched a movie with a friend, and it was interesting.

examples.kr: 어제 저는 엄마랑 시장에 갔어요, 우리는 많은 식료품을 샀어요.
examples.romaji: Eoje jeoneun eommarang sijange gasseoyo, urineun maneun singnyopumeul sasseoyo.
examples.en: Yesterday, I went to the market with my mom, and we bought a lot of groceries.

examples.kr: 나는 동생이랑 공원에서 놀았어요, 우리는 많이 즐거웠어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun dongsaengirang gongwoneseo norasseoyo, urineun mani jeulgeowosseoyo.
examples.en: I played in the park with my younger sibling, and we had a great time.

examples.kr: 오늘 점심시간에 친구랑 음악을 들었어요, 그 음악이 너무 좋았어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul jeomsimsigan-e chingurang eumageul deureosseoyo, geu eumagi neomu joasseoyo.
examples.en: At lunchtime today, I listened to music with a friend, and it was really good.

title: 그런데 [geureonde] (However, but)
short_explanation: Used to indicate contrast or contradiction; 'however', 'but'.
long_explanation: '그런데 [geureonde]' is a transitional phrase used to introduce a statement that contradicts or contrasts with the previous statement. It can mean 'however', 'but', or 'though' in English. It often shifts the direction of the conversation or highlights an unexpected twist.

examples.kr: 처음에는 그 과제가 쉬워 보였어요, 그런데 실제로 해보니 매우 어려웠어요.
examples.romaji: Cheoeumeneun geu gwajega swiweo boyeosseoyo, geureonde siljero hae boni maeu eoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: At first, the assignment seemed easy, but once I actually did it, it was very hard.

examples.kr: 저는 가장 좋아하는 스포츠가 농구인데, 그런데 제 친구는 농구를 전혀 좋아하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gajang joahaneun seupocheuga nongguinde, geureonde je chinguneun nonggureul jeonhyeo joahaji anhayo.
examples.en: My favorite sport is basketball, but my friend doesn't like basketball at all.

examples.kr: 어제 영화관에 갔는데, 그런데 영화가 이미 시작된 후였어요.
examples.romaji: Eoje yeonghwagwane gasseunde, geureonde yeonghwaga imi sijakdoen hueosseoyo.
examples.en: I went to the cinema yesterday, but the movie had already started.

examples.kr: 친구가 이 청바지를 추천해 줬는데, 그런데 제 스타일에 맞지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga i cheongbajireul chucheonhae junneunde, geureonde je seutair-e matji anhayo.
examples.en: My friend recommended these jeans, but they don't suit my style.

title: 그래서 [geuraeseo] (So, therefore)
short_explanation: Used to show a cause-and-effect relationship; 'so', 'therefore'.
long_explanation: '그래서 [geuraeseo]' is a conjunctive adverb that indicates the result or conclusion of the preceding clause. It's similar to 'so' or 'therefore' in English. The second sentence (after '그래서') explains the logical outcome or effect of the first sentence.

examples.kr: 오늘은 간단하게 먹으려고 했는데, 친구가 맛있는 음식을 가져왔어요. 그래서 많이 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun gandanage meogeuryeogo haetneunde, chinguga masinneun eumsigeul gajyeowasseoyo. Geuraeseo manhi meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: I planned to eat lightly today, but my friend brought delicious food. So I ate a lot.

examples.kr: 전 책을 읽는 것을 좋아해요. 그래서 한 달에 여러 권의 책을 읽어요.
examples.romaji: Jeon chaegeul ilgneun geoseul joahaeyo. Geuraeseo han dale yeoreo gwonui chaegeul ilgeoyo.
examples.en: I like reading books. So I read several books each month.

examples.kr: 어제 공부를 너무 많이 했어요. 그래서 오늘은 쉬어야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Eoje gongbureul neomu mani haesseoyo. Geuraeseo oneureun swieoyagess-eoyo.
examples.en: I studied too much yesterday. So I should rest today.

examples.kr: 주말에는 늦게까지 자서 일어나지 못했어요. 그래서 점심이 되어 버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Jumaleneun neutgekkaji jaseo il-eonaji mothaesseoyo. Geuraeseo jeomsimi doeeo beoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: I slept late on the weekend and couldn't wake up. So it ended up being lunchtime.

title: 그리고 [geurigo] (And then)
short_explanation: Used to link consecutive actions or events, often translated as 'and then'.
long_explanation: '그리고 [geurigo]' is a conjunction in Korean that links events or actions occurring in sequence. It implies continuation or succession, like 'and then' in English. It's common in narratives or step-by-step descriptions.

examples.kr: 저는 학교에 갔어요 그리고 수업을 들었어요 그리고 친구들과 점심을 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hakgyoe gasseoyo geurigo sueopeul deuleosseoyo geurigo chingudeulgwa jeomsimeul meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: I went to school, and then I took classes, and then I had lunch with friends.

examples.kr: 게임을 했어요 그리고 졸려서 잠을 잤어요 그리고 다시 게임을 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geimeul haesseoyo geurigo jollyeoseo jameul jasseoyo geurigo dasi geimeul haesseoyo.
examples.en: I played a game, and then I got sleepy and slept, and then I played again.

examples.kr: 제가 커피를 마셨어요 그리고 도서관에 갔어요 그리고 공부를 했어요.
examples.romaji: Jega keopireul masyeosseoyo geurigo doseogwane gaseoyo geurigo gongbureul haesseoyo.
examples.en: I drank coffee, and then I went to the library, and then I studied.

examples.kr: 친구를 만났어요 그리고 영화를 봤어요 그리고 집에 돌아왔어요.
examples.romaji: Chingureul mannasseoyo geurigo yeonghwareul bwasseoyo geurigo jibe dolawasseoyo.
examples.en: I met a friend, and then we watched a movie, and then I came home.

title: 아/어/여 주다 [a/eo/yeo juda] (To do for someone)
short_explanation: Used to express doing an action for someone’s benefit.
long_explanation: '아/어/여 주다' is a verb ending that means doing something *for* or *on behalf of* someone else. It attaches to the verb stem (with 아/어/여 depending on the stem’s final vowel), followed by '주다'. It often suggests kindness, favor, or helping the other person.

examples.kr: 제가 수업 노트를 정리해서 친구에게 메일로 보내주었어요.
examples.romaji: Jega sueop noteureul jeongnihaeseo chinguege meillo bonaejueosseoyo.
examples.en: I organized the class notes and sent them to my friend by email.

examples.kr: 서민이가 청소를 해주는 것을 본 뒤에 저도 청소를 도와주었어요.
examples.romaji: Seominiga cheongso-reul haejuneun geoseul bon dwie jeodo cheongso-reul dowajueosseoyo.
examples.en: After seeing Seomin clean, I ended up helping with the cleaning too.

examples.kr: 어려운 문제 때문에 고민했는데, 선생님이 해결 방법을 알려주셨어요.
examples.romaji: Eoryeoun munje ttaemune gominhaetneunde, seonsaengnim-i haegyeol bangbeobeul allyeojusyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I was struggling with a difficult problem, and the teacher showed me the solution.

examples.kr: 맛있는 음식을 만들어서 친구들에게 저녁을 챙겨주는 걸 좋아해요.
examples.romaji: Masinneun eumsigeul mandeureoseo chingudeurege jeonyeogeul chaenggyeojuneun geol johahaeyo.
examples.en: I like making delicious food and serving dinner to my friends.

title: 아/어/여 하다 [a/eo/yeo hada] (To feel or show a certain emotion)
short_explanation: Used mainly to convert adjectives (descriptive verbs) into active verbs that show one’s feeling or reaction.
long_explanation: In Korean, some descriptive verbs (adjectives) become active verbs when combined with '아/어/여 하다'. For example, '슬프다' (to be sad) → '슬퍼하다' (to feel or show sadness). It indicates that the subject actively experiences or outwardly shows the emotion/state. This pattern is especially common with psychological or emotional adjectives.

examples.kr: 그는 영화가 너무 슬퍼서 울기도 하고 슬퍼해요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun yeonghwaga neomu seulpeoseo ulgido hago seulpeohaeyo.
examples.en: He finds the movie so sad that he cries and expresses his sadness.

examples.kr: 아이가 무서워해서 혼자 자는 것을 싫어해요.
examples.romaji: Aiga museowohaeseo honja janeun geoseul sil-eohaeyo.
examples.en: The child is scared, so he dislikes sleeping alone.

examples.kr: 그녀는 부끄러워하여 사람들 앞에 나서길 망설였어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun bukkeureowohayeo saramdeul ape naseogil mangseoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: She felt embarrassed and hesitated to stand in front of people.

examples.kr: 사람들은 그 소식을 듣고 몹시 놀라워했어요.
examples.romaji: Saramdeureun geu sosigeul deutgo mopsi nollawohaesseoyo.
examples.en: People were very astonished when they heard the news.

title: 의 [ui] (Possessive marker)
short_explanation: Used to denote possession or relationship; similar to '’s' in English.
long_explanation: The marker '의 [ui]' indicates a possessive or descriptive relationship between two nouns. It is similar to English apostrophe-s ('s), or 'of' in some contexts. It can show ownership, belonging, or other relationships (e.g., family relationships, origin, material).

examples.kr: 이것은 나의 책이에요, 그래서 누구에게도 주지 않을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Igeoseun naui chaegieyo, geuraeseo nuguegedo juji anheul geoyeyo.
examples.en: This is my book, so I'm not going to give it to anyone.

examples.kr: 부탁드려요, 저의 주차 공간을 차지하지 말아 주세요.
examples.romaji: Butakdeuryeoyo, jeoui jucha gongganeul chajihaji mara juseyo.
examples.en: Please do not occupy my parking space.

examples.kr: 그녀는 그녀의 강아지를 정말 많이 사랑해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun geunyeoui gangajireul jeongmal manhi saranghaeyo.
examples.en: She really loves her puppy.

examples.kr: 이것은 그의 아버지의 오래된 시계예요.
examples.romaji: Igeoseun geuui abeojiui oraedoen sigyeyeyo.
examples.en: This is his father's old watch.

title: (으)로 [(eu)ro] (To, toward; by means of)
short_explanation: Used to express direction, method, or transformation ('to', 'toward', 'by', 'into').
long_explanation: '(으)로 [(eu)ro]' is a Korean particle with several functions. It can indicate direction ('to/toward'), method or instrument ('by/with/using'), or transformation ('into'). After a consonant, use '으로'; after a vowel, just '로'.

examples.kr: 나는 매일 아침 지하철로 학교에 가요.
examples.romaji: Naneun maeil achim jihacheollo hakgyoe gayo.
examples.en: I go to school by subway every morning.

examples.kr: 우리 아빠는 요리를 재료로 사랑을 표현해요.
examples.romaji: Uri appaneun yorireul jaeryoro sarangeul pyohyeonhaeyo.
examples.en: My father shows his love through cooking ingredients.

examples.kr: 그 회사는 종이를 재활용해서 노트북으로 만들어요.
examples.romaji: Geu hoesaneun jongireul jaehwallyonghaeseo noteubugeuro mandeureoyo.
examples.en: That company recycles paper and makes it into notebooks.

examples.kr: 문을 열기 위해 열쇠로 문을 돌려요.
examples.romaji: Muneul yeolgi wihae yeolswero muneul dolryeoyo.
examples.en: I turn the key in order to open the door.

title: 한테/에게 [hante/ege] (To someone)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the recipient or target of an action; roughly 'to' in English.
long_explanation: '한테 [hante]' and '에게 [ege]' both mean 'to (a person)' in Korean. '에게' is slightly more formal, whereas '한테' is more colloquial. They specify to whom or to what an action is directed (e.g., giving, telling, teaching).

examples.kr: 제가 어제 친구에게 선물을 줬어요.
examples.romaji: Jega eoje chinguege seonmureul jwosseoyo.
examples.en: I gave a gift to my friend yesterday.

examples.kr: 제 목소리를 직접 그녀에게 들려주고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Je mogsorireul jikjeop geunyeoege deullyeojugo sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I want her to hear my voice in person.

examples.kr: 언니한테 좋은 뉴스를 전하고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Eonni-hante joheun nyuseureul jeonhago sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I want to tell my older sister the good news.

examples.kr: 어머니한테 저녁 식사를 준비해드렸어요.
examples.romaji: Eomeoni-hante jeonyeok siksareul junbihaedeuryeosseoyo.
examples.en: I prepared dinner for my mother.

title: 한테서/에서 [hanteseo/eseo] (From someone)
short_explanation: Used to denote the source or origin; 'from'.
long_explanation: '한테서/에서 [hanteseo/eseo]' indicates the source or place from which something (an object, idea, or action) originates. '한테서' is used when receiving something from a person, and '에서' is used for inanimate sources or places. For example, when you get a letter from a friend, you use '친구한테서'; when you borrow a book from the library, you use '도서관에서.'
formation: Noun + 한테서 (person) / 에서 (place or inanimate source)

examples.kr: 친구한테서 편지를 받았어요. 그는 항상 연락을 잘 해 줘요.
examples.romaji: Chinguhanteseo pyeonjireul badasseoyo. Geuneun hangsang yeollageul jal hae jwoyo.
examples.en: I received a letter from a friend. He always keeps in good touch.

examples.kr: 서울에서 부산까지 차로 얼마나 걸릴까요?
examples.romaji: Seoul-eseo Busan-kkaji charo eolmana geolrilkkayo?
examples.en: How long does it take to get from Seoul to Busan by car?

examples.kr: 제가 이 책을 도서관에서 빌렸어요.
examples.romaji: Jega i chaekeul doseogwaneseo billyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I borrowed this book from the library.

examples.kr: 그 음식은 어머니한테서 배웠어요.
examples.romaji: Geu eumsigeun eomeonihanteseo baeweosseoyo.
examples.en: I learned how to make that dish from my mother.

title: 보다 [boda] (More than)
short_explanation: Used to express comparison; 'more than' or simply 'than'.
long_explanation: '보다 [boda]' is a comparative marker in Korean. It follows the standard or benchmark being compared, while the element outside or after '보다' is the one being described as 'more' (or 'less') in some aspect. In English, this often corresponds to 'than' or 'more than.'

examples.kr: 저는 커피보다 차를 더 좋아해요. 차가 제 입맛에 더 잘 맞아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun keopiboda chareul deo joahaeyo. Chaga je ibmase deo jal majayo.
examples.en: I prefer tea over coffee. Tea suits my taste better than coffee.

examples.kr: 우리 집은 도서관보다 책이 더 많아요. 가족 모두가 독서를 사랑해서 그렇게 됐어요.
examples.romaji: Uri jibeun doseogwanboda chaegi deo manhayo. Gajok moduga dokseoreul saranghaeseo geureohge dwaesseoyo.
examples.en: We have more books at home than the library. It turned out that way because everyone in my family loves reading.

examples.kr: 한국어를 배우는 것은 중국어를 배우는 것보다 쉬워요. 필기와 발음이 더 단순하니까요.
examples.romaji: Hangugeoreul baeuneun geoseun junggugeoreul baeuneun geotboda swiwoyo. Pilgiwa bareumi deo dansunhanikkayo.
examples.en: Learning Korean is easier than learning Chinese, because the writing system and pronunciation are simpler.

examples.kr: 지금은 여름이지만, 봄보다 날씨가 더 추워요. 이상한 기후 변화 때문인 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Jigeumeun yeoreumijiman, bomboda nalssiga deo chuwoyo. Isanghan gihu byeonhwa ttaemun in geot gatayo.
examples.en: It's summer now, but it's colder than spring. It seems to be because of strange climate changes.

title: 가장 [gajang] (The most)
short_explanation: Used to express the superlative degree; 'the most', 'the best'.
long_explanation: '가장 [gajang]' is an adverb meaning 'most,' indicating the highest degree or superlative level of a characteristic. It can modify verbs, adjectives, or even some adverbs, conveying the sense of 'the most' or 'the best.'

examples.kr: 저는 가장 좋아하는 사람과 결혼하고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gajang joahaneun saramgwa gyeolhonhago sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I want to marry the person I love the most.

examples.kr: 가장 먼저 도착한 사람이 상품을 받을 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Gajang meonjeo dochakhan sarami sangpumeul bad-eul su isseoyo.
examples.en: Whoever arrives first will be able to get the prize.

examples.kr: 그는 가장 힘들었던 시절에도 포기하지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun gajang himdeuleossdeon sijeol-edo pogihaji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: He didn't give up even during the hardest times.

examples.kr: 저는 가장 큰 꿈을 이루고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gajang keun kkum-eul ilugo sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I want to achieve my biggest dream.

title: 도 [do] (Even)
short_explanation: Used to emphasize inclusion or an extreme; 'even', 'also', 'too'.
long_explanation: '도 [do]' is a particle that can mean 'too,' 'also,' or 'even,' depending on context. It often emphasizes the additional inclusion of an item or an extreme case, suggesting that the statement applies in that situation as well.

examples.kr: 나는 한국어도 잘하고, 일본어도 잘해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun hangugeodo jalhago, ilboneodo jalhaeyo.
examples.en: I speak Korean well, and I also speak Japanese well.

examples.kr: 그는 잘생겼을 뿐만 아니라 성격도 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun jalsaenggyeosseul ppunman anira seonggyeokdo joayo.
examples.en: Not only is he handsome, but his personality is also good.

examples.kr: 이 식당은 음식도 맛있고, 분위기도 좋아요.
examples.romaji: I sikdangeun eumsikdo masitgo, bunwigido joayo.
examples.en: This restaurant's food is delicious, and the atmosphere is also nice.

examples.kr: 나는 어제 집에 도착했을 때 밤 12시도 넘었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun eoje jibe dochakhaet-eul ttae bam yeoldusido neomeosseoyo.
examples.en: When I arrived home yesterday, it was even past midnight.

title: 이/그/저 [i/geu/jeo] (This, that, that over there)
short_explanation: Used to indicate spatial relationships: 'this' (close), 'that' (far), 'that over there' (farther).
long_explanation: '이/그/저' are demonstratives in Korean. '이' is used for something close to the speaker ('this'), '그' for something near the listener or previously mentioned but not in the speaker's reach ('that'), and '저' for something far from both speaker and listener ('that over there').

examples.kr: 이 펜은 제 펜입니다. 그 펜은 당신의 펜입니다. 저 펜은 누구 것인지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: I peneun je penimnida. Geu peneun dangsin-ui penimnida. Jeo peneun nugu geos-inji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: This pen is mine. That pen is yours. I don't know whose pen that one over there is.

examples.kr: 이 핸드폰은 버그가 많아요. 그 핸드폰은 성능이 좋아요. 저 핸드폰은 무슨 모델인지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: I haendeupon-eun beogeuga manhayo. Geu haendeupon-eun seongneungi joayo. Jeo haendeupon-eun museun model-inji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: This phone has many bugs. That phone performs well. I don't know what model that phone over there is.

examples.kr: 이 음식은 맛이 없어요. 그 음식은 매워요. 저 음식은 어떤 맛인지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: I eumsik-eun masi eobseoyo. Geu eumsik-eun maewoyo. Jeo eumsik-eun eotteon mas-inji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: This food has no taste. That food is spicy. I don't know what that food over there tastes like.

examples.kr: 이 책은 재미있어요. 그 책은 너무 어려워요. 저 책은 어떤 내용인지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: I chaekeun jaemiisseoyo. Geu chaekeun neomu eoryeowoyo. Jeo chaekeun eotteon naeyong-inji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: This book is interesting. That book is too difficult. I don't know what that book over there is about.

title: (이)나 [(i)na] (Or)
short_explanation: Used to express alternatives; 'or'.
long_explanation: '(이)나 [(i)na]' is used after nouns (and sometimes verbs in certain constructions) to present alternatives or choices. It can be roughly translated to 'or' in English. For verbs, the more common form is '-거나,' but '(이)나' can appear after verbs in some contexts, especially in casual speech.
formation: Noun + (이)나 / Verb + (이)나 (colloquial), Verb + 거나 (standard for verbs)

examples.kr: 피자나 햄버거 중에 뭐 먹고 싶어요?
examples.romaji: Pijana haembeogeo junge mwo meokgo sip-eoyo?
examples.en: Do you want pizza or a hamburger?

examples.kr: 저는 주말에 친구들이랑 영화 보러 가거나 쇼핑을 하러 갈 거예요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun jumare chingudeulirang yeonghwa boreo ganeunga syopingeul hareo gal geoyeyo.
examples.en: On the weekend, I'll either go watch a movie with my friends or go shopping.

examples.kr: 빨래나 설거지 같은 집안일을 해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Ppallae na seolgeoji gateun jibanireul haeya haeyo.
examples.en: I have to do household chores like laundry or washing the dishes.

examples.kr: 오늘 밤에는 숙제를 하거나 책을 읽을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Oneul bamen-eun sukjereul hageona chaekeul ilgeul geoyeyo.
examples.en: Tonight, I will either do homework or read a book.

title: 밖에 [bakke] (Only, except)
short_explanation: Used to express 'only' or 'nothing but', typically with a negative verb.
long_explanation: '밖에 [bakke]' is used after a noun to emphasize that there is nothing else other than the noun in question. It usually pairs with a negative verb form to convey the idea of exclusivity or limitation—similar to 'only' or 'nothing but' in English (e.g., '할 수밖에 없다' = 'I have no choice but to do it').

examples.kr: 나는 이번 주말에 집에 있을 수밖에 없었어요, 모든 친구들이 바빴거든요.
examples.romaji: Naneun ibeon jumare jibe isseul subakke eopseosseoyo, modeun chingudeuri bappatgeodeunyo.
examples.en: I had no choice but to stay home this weekend, because all my friends were busy.

examples.kr: 엄마는 부엌에서 요리하는 것밖에 몰라서 다른 일을 잘 못해요.
examples.romaji: Eommaneun bu-eok-eseo yorihaneun geotbakke mollaseo dareun ireul jal mothaeyo.
examples.en: My mom doesn't know how to do anything except cooking in the kitchen.

examples.kr: 나는 한국어밖에 몰라서 다른 언어로 이야기하기가 어려워요.
examples.romaji: Naneun hanguk-eobakke mollaseo dareun eoneoro iyagihagiga eoryeowoyo.
examples.en: I only know Korean, so it's hard for me to speak in other languages.

examples.kr: 그 학생은 공부밖에 몰라서 놀거나 다른 일을 잘 못해요.
examples.romaji: Geu haksaengeun gongbubakke mollaseo nolgeona dareun ireul jal mothaeyo.
examples.en: That student only knows how to study, so he's not good at playing or doing other things.

title: 뿐 [ppun] (Only)
short_explanation: Used in positive sentences to express that only the stated thing is true or valid.
long_explanation: '뿐 [ppun]' is similar to '밖에', but it's used in positive sentences to say 'only' or 'just' that one thing/situation is the case—often emphasizing exclusivity without requiring a negative verb. You might also see it combined as '뿐만 아니라' meaning 'not only…but also.'

examples.kr: 우리 집에는 고양이 두 마리뿐이에요. 다른 애완동물은 없어요.
examples.romaji: Uri jibe-neun goyangi du mari ppunieyo. Dareun aewandongmuleun eopseoyo.
examples.en: We only have two cats at home; there are no other pets.

examples.kr: 주말에는 집에서 휴식하는 것뿐이지, 특별한 일정은 없어요.
examples.romaji: Jumaleneun jibeseo hyusikhaneun geotppuniji, teukbyeolhan iljeongeun eopseoyo.
examples.en: All I do on weekends is rest at home; I don't have any special plans.

examples.kr: 저는 커피뿐 아니라 차도 좋아해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun keopippun anira chado joahaeyo.
examples.en: I like not only coffee but also tea.

examples.kr: 제가 할 수 있는 건 이것뿐입니다. 최선을 다했어요.
examples.romaji: Jega hal su inneun geon igeotppunimnida. Choeseoneul dahaesseoyo.
examples.en: This is all I can do. I've done my best.

title: 는/은 것 [neun/eun geot] (The thing that…, nominalizing)
short_explanation: Nominalizes verbs or adjectives, translating roughly as 'the act of …ing' or 'the thing that…'.
long_explanation: The construction '는/은 것 [neun/eun geot]' is used in Korean to turn verbs or adjectives into noun phrases—'the thing that…' or 'the act of …ing.' You use '는' after a present verb stem (e.g., '보다' → '보는 것'), and '은' after an adjective stem or a past verb stem to make it function like a noun in the sentence.

examples.kr: 영화를 보는 것이 왜 그렇게 재미있는지 이해가 안 돼요.
examples.romaji: Yeonghwareul boneun geosi wae geureohge jaemiinneunji ihaega an dwaeyo.
examples.en: I don't understand why watching movies is so fun.

examples.kr: 우리 나라에서 사는 것은 정말로 재미있습니다.
examples.romaji: Uri nara-eseo saneun geoseun jeongmallo jaemiisseumnida.
examples.en: Living in our country is really fun.

examples.kr: 가장 중요한 것은 솔직한 거예요.
examples.romaji: Gajang jungyohan geoseun soljikhan geoyeyo.
examples.en: The most important thing is being honest.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 배우는 것이 어렵지만, 계속 연습하고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul baeuneun geosi eoryeopjiman, gyesok yeonseubhago sip-eoyo.
examples.en: Learning Korean is difficult for me, but I still want to keep practicing.

title: (으)ㄴ/는 것 같다 [(eu)n/neun geot gatda] (It seems like)
short_explanation: Used to express a conjecture, guess, or resemblance; 'it seems like', 'it appears that'.
long_explanation: '(으)ㄴ/는 것 같다' is a common structure in Korean for expressing a guess or impression about a situation. With **action verbs**, '는 것 같다' typically indicates a current action or a general impression; with **descriptive verbs** (adjectives) or **past tense verbs**, '(으)ㄴ 것 같다' is used. It loosely translates to 'it seems that...' or 'it looks like...'.
formation: Action verb + 는 것 같다 / Descriptive or past verb + (으)ㄴ 것 같다

examples.kr: 날씨가 춥다고 생각했는데, 밖은 따뜻한 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga chubdago saenggakhaetneunde, bak-eun ttatteuthan geot gatayo.
examples.en: I thought it was cold, but it seems warm outside.

examples.kr: 그 여자는 아주 친절한 것 같습니다. 주변 사람들에게 항상 웃는 얼굴로 대하니까요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeojaneun aju chinjeolhan geot gatsseumnida. Jubyeon saramdeurege hangsang utneun eolgullo daehanikkayo.
examples.en: That woman seems really kind, as she always greets people with a smile.

examples.kr: 주인공이 결국엔 성공할 것 같아요. 왜냐하면 어려움을 극복하려고 무척 노력하니까요.
examples.romaji: Ju-ingongi gyeolgugen seonggonghal geot gatayo. Waenyahamyeon eoryeoumeul geukbokharyeogo mucheok noryeokhanikkayo.
examples.en: I think the protagonist will succeed in the end because he puts a lot of effort into overcoming difficulties.

examples.kr: 이번 시험은 어려울 것 같아요. 배운 내용이 많이 복잡하거든요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon siheomeun eoryeoul geot gatayo. Baeun naeyongi manhi bokjaphageodeunyo.
examples.en: I think this test will be difficult, because the material we learned is quite complex.

title: (으)러 가다/오다 [(eu)reo gada/oda] (Go/come to do something)
short_explanation: Used to express the purpose of going or coming somewhere; 'go/come to do something'.
long_explanation: '(으)러 가다/오다' is used to indicate **why** someone goes or comes to a location. If the verb stem ends in a consonant, you add '(으)러'; if it ends in a vowel, you add '러'. It translates to 'go/come in order to do (something)'. For instance: 가다 → 가러, 먹다 → 먹으러, 배우다 → 배우러.
formation: Consonant-ending verb stem + (으)러 가다/오다, Vowel-ending verb stem + 러 가다/오다

examples.kr: 나는 친구를 만나러 학교에 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chingureul mannareo hakgyoe gasseoyo.
examples.en: I went to school to meet a friend.

examples.kr: 내일 부모님을 찾아뵈러 고향에 가려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Naeil bumonimeul chajabwero gohyange garyeogo haeyo.
examples.en: I'm planning to go to my hometown tomorrow to visit my parents.

examples.kr: 그녀는 새 신발을 사러 쇼핑몰에 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun sae sinbareul sareo syopingmole gasseoyo.
examples.en: She went to the mall to buy new shoes.

examples.kr: 저는 스피치를 준비하러 도서관에 왔습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun seupichireul junbihareo doseogwane wassseumnida.
examples.en: I came to the library to prepare a speech.

title: 아/어/여도 [a/eo/yeodo] (Even if)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that a certain condition does not affect the main action or conclusion; 'even if'.
long_explanation: '아/어/여도' means 'even if' or 'even though.' It attaches to the verb stem, showing that **even if** the condition in that clause happens, the main action or state **still** occurs regardless. For example, '늦어도 (even if you’re late)' or '비가 와도 (even if it rains)'.

examples.kr: 비가 와도 학교에 가야 했어요. 시험이 있었거든요.
examples.romaji: Biga wado hakgyoe gaya haesseoyo. Siheomi isseotgeodeunyo.
examples.en: Even if it rained, I had to go to school, because there was a test.

examples.kr: 친구가 늦어도 기다릴 거예요. 우리는 오래된 친구니까요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga neujeodo gidaril geoyeyo. Urineun oraedoen chingunikka-yo.
examples.en: Even if my friend is late, I'll wait, because we've been friends for a long time.

examples.kr: 감기가 심해도 축구를 해야 해요. 팀원을 실망시키고 싶지 않거든요.
examples.romaji: Gamgiga simhaedo chukgureul haeya haeyo. Timwon-eul silmang sikigo sipji angeodeunyo.
examples.en: Even if I have a bad cold, I have to play soccer. I don't want to let my teammates down.

examples.kr: 날씨가 추워져도 산책을 계속할 거예요. 그게 스트레스 해소에 최고예요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga chuwojyeodo sanchaegeul gyesokhal geoyeyo. Geuge seuteureseu haesoe choegoyeyo.
examples.en: Even if the weather gets cold, I'll keep taking walks. It's the best way to relieve stress.

title: 계속 [gyesok] (Continue to)
short_explanation: Used to express the ongoing or repeated nature of an action or state.
long_explanation: '계속 [gyesok]' means 'continuously' or 'keep (doing something)'. It shows that an action remains unbroken or is repeated over a period. It can also apply to states or conditions, indicating they persist without stopping.

examples.kr: 그는 계속 공부하고 있어서 시험을 잘 볼 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun gyesok gongbuhago isseoseo siheomeul jal bol geot gatayo.
examples.en: He continues studying, so I think he'll do well on the test.

examples.kr: 기분이 좋아서 저는 계속 웃고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Gibuni joaseo jeoneun gyesok usgo isseoyo.
examples.en: I'm in a good mood, so I keep laughing.

examples.kr: 비가 계속 오고 있어서 우산을 챙기는 게 좋을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Biga gyesok ogo isseoseo usaneul chaenggineun ge joeul geot gatayo.
examples.en: It's still raining, so it would be good to take an umbrella.

examples.kr: 그녀는 계속 건강에 신경 쓰고 있어요, 그래서 아플 확률이 적어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun gyesok geongange singyeong sseugo isseoyo, geuraeseo apeul hwagnyuli jeogeoyo.
examples.en: She keeps taking care of her health, so the chances of her getting sick are low.

title: 항상 [hangsang] (Always)
short_explanation: Used to indicate something that happens at all times or consistently.
long_explanation: '항상 [hangsang]' is an adverb that means 'always.' It indicates a repeated or continuous habit, behavior, or situation. Whether it’s past, present, or future, '항상' emphasizes the consistency or habitual nature of the action.

examples.kr: 저는 항상 아침에 일찍 일어나서 학교에 가요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangsang achime iljjik ireonaseo hakgyoe gayo.
examples.en: I always wake up early in the morning and go to school.

examples.kr: 우리 엄마는 항상 저녁 식사를 준비하면서 라디오를 들어요.
examples.romaji: Uri eommaneun hangsang jeonyeok siksareul junbihamyeonseo radioreul deureoyo.
examples.en: My mom always listens to the radio while preparing dinner.

examples.kr: 그는 항상 공부 계획을 철저하게 세우고 그대로 따라요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hangsang gongbu gyehoekeul cheoljeohage seugo geudaero ddarayo.
examples.en: He always makes thorough study plans and follows them exactly.

examples.kr: 공원에서는 항상 새들이 노래를 부르고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Gongwoneseoneun hangsang saedeuri noraereul bureugo isseoyo.
examples.en: In the park, birds are always singing.

title: (으)ㄹ 때 [(eu)l ttae] (When)
short_explanation: Used to express 'when' something happens or a time condition.
long_explanation: '(으)ㄹ 때' corresponds to 'when' or 'at the time that' in English. It's used to link a time clause with the main clause, indicating when an action or state occurs. If the verb stem ends in a vowel, you add 'ㄹ 때,' and if it ends in a consonant, you add '을 때.'
formation: Verb stem + ㄹ 때 (vowel-ending) / 을 때 (consonant-ending)

examples.kr: 여름에는 우리 집에서 바다를 볼 때 창문을 열면 시원한 바닷바람이 들어와요.
examples.romaji: Yeoreumeneun uri jibeseo badareul bol ttae changmuneul yeolmyeon siwonhan badatbarami deureowayo.
examples.en: In the summer, when we look at the ocean from our house and open the window, a cool sea breeze comes in.

examples.kr: 학교에 갈 때 버스를 타면 편해요.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoe gal ttae beoseureul tamyeon pyeonhaeyo.
examples.en: When going to school, it's convenient to take the bus.

examples.kr: 숙제를 할 때 음악을 들으면 더 집중할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Sukjereul hal ttae eumageul deureumyeon deo jipjunghal su isseoyo.
examples.en: When doing homework, listening to music helps me concentrate better.

examples.kr: 친구를 만날 때 함께 식사하면 더 즐거워요.
examples.romaji: Chingureul mannal ttae hamkke siksahamyeon deo jeulgeowoyo.
examples.en: When meeting a friend, it's more fun if you eat together.

title: 아/어/여야 되다 [a/eo/yeoya doeda] (Must, have to)
short_explanation: Used to express obligation or necessity; 'must', 'have to'.
long_explanation: '아/어/여야 되다' conveys an obligation or necessity, similar to 'must' or 'have to' in English. It is attached to the verb stem with the appropriate connector (아, 어, or 여), followed by '야 되다'. This indicates the speaker believes that action is required or unavoidable.

examples.kr: 병원에 가려면 건강 검사를 받아야 돼요. 그래야 안심하고 공부할 수 있죠.
examples.romaji: Byeongwone garyeomyeon geongang geomsa-reul bad-aya dwaeyo. Geuraeya ansimhago gongbuhal su itjyo.
examples.en: If you want to go to the hospital, you must get a health checkup. Only then can you study with peace of mind.

examples.kr: 이번 달 매출을 늘리려면 더 많은 고객을 끌어들여야 돼요. 그래야 수익이 오를 거예요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon dal maechuleul neulliryeomyeon deo manheun gogaegeul kkeureodeuryeoya dwaeyo. Geuraeya su-igi oreul geoyeyo.
examples.en: To increase this month's sales, you have to attract more customers. That's how the profit will go up.

examples.kr: 학교에 가기 전에는 아침 식사를 꼭 해야 돼요. 그래야 하루 종일 에너지를 유지하거든요.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoe gagi jeoneneun achim siksareul kkok haeya dwaeyo. Geuraeya haru jongil eneojireul yujihageodeunyo.
examples.en: You must eat breakfast before going to school. That way you can maintain your energy all day.

examples.kr: 내일 시험이 있으니까 오늘 밤에 공부해야 돼요. 안 그러면 점수가 안 좋을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Naeil siheomi issnikka oneul bame gongbuhaeya dwaeyo. An geureomyeon jeomsuga an joeul geoyeyo.
examples.en: I have an exam tomorrow, so I must study tonight. Otherwise, I'll get a bad score.

title: (으)면서 [(eu)myeonseo] (While, and)
short_explanation: Used to express two actions happening at the same time; 'while doing X, doing Y'.
long_explanation: '(으)면서' shows that two actions or states occur simultaneously. If the verb stem ends in a consonant, add '으면서'; if it ends in a vowel, just '면서'. For example, 먹다 → 먹으면서, 가다 → 가면서. It can translate to 'while ~ing' in English.
formation: Consonant-ending verb + 으면서 / Vowel-ending verb + 면서

examples.kr: 나는 텔레비전을 보면서 식사를 했어요. 그래서 대화는 못 했죠.
examples.romaji: Naneun tellebijeoneul bomyeonseo siksareul haesseoyo. Geuraeseo daehwaneun mot haetjyo.
examples.en: I ate while watching TV, so I couldn't talk.

examples.kr: 그녀는 버스에서 음악을 들으면서 책을 읽고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun beoseueseo eumageul deuleumyeonseo chaegeul ilgo isseoyo.
examples.en: She is reading a book while listening to music on the bus.

examples.kr: 요즘 내 동생은 학교 공부를 하면서 아르바이트도 하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Yojeum nae dongsaengeun hakgyo gongbureul hamyeonseo areubaiteu-do hago isseoyo.
examples.en: These days, my younger sibling is studying and also doing a part-time job.

examples.kr: 나는 팟캐스트를 들으면서 새 단어를 기록하고 있어요. 듣기 실력을 늘리려구요.
examples.romaji: Naneun patkaeseuteureul deuleumyeonseo sae daneoreul girokago isseoyo. Deutgi sillyeogeul neulliryeoguyo.
examples.en: I listen to podcasts while writing down new words, hoping to improve my listening skills.

title: 다가 [daga] (And then, while)
short_explanation: Used to show that one action was interrupted or followed by another action.
long_explanation: '다가' indicates that an action was in progress when another action or event occurred, often with an element of interruption or a sequence. In English, it might be 'while doing X, Y happened' or 'I was doing X, and then Y occurred.'

examples.kr: 저는 책을 읽다가 잠이 와서 잠들었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun chaekeul ilgdaga jami waseo jamdeureosseoyo.
examples.en: I was reading a book, then I got sleepy and fell asleep.

examples.kr: 식당에 가서 밥을 먹다가 친구를 만났어요.
examples.romaji: Sikdange gaseo babeul meokdaga chingureul manasseoyo.
examples.en: I went to the restaurant to eat, and while eating, I happened to meet a friend.

examples.kr: 음악을 듣다가 갑자기 전화가 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Eumageul deudgaga gabjagi jeonhwaga wasseoyo.
examples.en: I was listening to music when suddenly the phone rang.

examples.kr: 저는 공부를 하다가 컴퓨터가 꺼져서 깜짝 놀랐어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gongbureul hadaga keompyuteoga ggeojyeoseo kkampjjak nollasseoyo.
examples.en: I was studying when the computer turned off, and it startled me.

title: 아/어/여 보이다 [a/eo/yeo boida] (Looks, seems)
short_explanation: Used to express 'it seems', 'it looks like', or 'appears to be'.
long_explanation: '아/어/여 보이다' is a Korean grammar pattern that describes the appearance or impression of someone or something, based on the speaker’s observation. It can relate to either physical appearance or a perceived mood or atmosphere. In English, it corresponds to expressions like 'it seems...', 'it looks...', or 'it appears...'.

examples.kr: 엄마는 행복해 보이는데, 아마 좋은 소식을 들었나 봐요.
examples.romaji: Eommaneun haengbokhae boineunde, ama jo-eun sosigeul deureotna bwayo.
examples.en: Mom looks happy. She probably heard some good news.

examples.kr: 그 사람은 늘 친절해 보이지만 실제로는 그렇지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Geu sarameun neul chinjeolhae boijiman siljeoroneun geureochi anhayo.
examples.en: That person always appears to be kind, but in reality, they aren’t.

examples.kr: 이 방은 너무 작아 보이지만, 인테리어를 잘 하면 충분히 쓸 만해요.
examples.romaji: I bangeun neomu jaga boijiman, inteorieoreul jal hamyeon chungbunhi sseul manhaeyo.
examples.en: This room looks very small, but if you decorate it well, it’s quite usable.

examples.kr: 너는 항상 바쁜 것 같아 보이는데, 어떻게 지내?
examples.romaji: Neoneun hangsang bappeun geot gata boineunde, eotteoke jinae?
examples.en: You always look busy—how have you been?

title: 아/어/여 버리다 [a/eo/yeo beorida] (Completely, regretfully)
short_explanation: Expresses that an action is done completely or with regret/surprise.
long_explanation: '아/어/여 버리다' is a grammatical form indicating that an action is carried out entirely or left a sense of regret, finality, or emotional surprise. It can mean 'to do something completely' or 'to end up doing something (with regret).' Depending on the final vowel of the verb stem, use 아, 어, or 여 before 버리다.

examples.kr: 저는 기다리다가 지쳐서 잠들어 버렸어요, 약속 시간에 친구를 못 만났어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gidaridaga jichyeoseo jamdeureo beoryeosseoyo, yaksok sigane chingureul mot mannasseoyo.
examples.en: I got tired of waiting and fell asleep, so I couldn’t meet my friend at the agreed time.

examples.kr: 그는 스트레스를 받아서 모든 것을 잊어버렸어요, 그런데 그게 반전이었어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun seuteureseureul badaseo modeun geoseul ijeobeoryeosseoyo, geureonde geuge banjeonieosseoyo.
examples.en: He was stressed out and forgot everything, but that turned out to be a twist.

examples.kr: 우리는 문제를 모두 분석해 봤지만, 결국 모든 것을 포기해 버렸어요.
