examples.romaji: Urineun munjereul modu bunseokhae bwatjiman, gyeolguk modeun geoseul pogihae beoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: We analyzed all the problems, but in the end, we just gave up on everything.

examples.kr: 주말이 왔지만, 불행히도 저는 모든 과제를 끝내 버렸어요. 그래서 쉴 시간이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Jumali watjiman, bulhaenghido jeoneun modeun gwaje-reul kkeutnae beoryeosseoyo. Geuraeseo swil sigani eopseoyo.
examples.en: The weekend came, but unfortunately, I finished all my assignments, so I have no time to rest.

title: 아/어/여 놓다 [a/eo/yeo nohda] (Leave something as is)
short_explanation: Used to describe leaving something in a certain state or condition.
long_explanation: '아/어/여 놓다' shows that after performing an action, you keep or maintain the resulting state. It implies that the speaker performed the action and deliberately left the object or situation as is. In English, you might say 'to leave (it) done' or 'have (it) done and left in place.'

examples.kr: 오늘은 집에 일찍 돌아와서 저녁 식사를 만들어 놓았어요. 저녁에 편하게 먹을 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun jibe iljjik dorawaseo jeonyeok siksareul mandeureo nohass-eoyo. Jeonyeoge pyeonhage meogeul su isseoyo.
examples.en: I came home early today and made dinner, so we can eat it comfortably in the evening.

examples.kr: 우리는 체크인하기 전에 호텔 방을 예약해 놓았어요. 그래서 바로 들어갈 수 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun chekeu-in hagi jeone hotel bangeul yeyaghae nohass-eoyo. Geuraeseo baro deureogal su isseosseoyo.
examples.en: We reserved our hotel room before check-in, so we could go right in.

examples.kr: 그는 오늘 계획을 다 짜 놓고는 아무것도 하지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun oneul gyehoeg-eul da jja nohkon-neun amugeotdo haji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: He drew up all the plans for today, and then did nothing.

examples.kr: 나는 시험을 위해 모든 공부를 해 놓았지만, 시험이 취소되었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun siheomeul wihae modeun gongbureul hae nohassjiman, siheomi chwiso doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: I finished all my study for the exam, but the exam got canceled.

title: 아/어/여 지다 [a/eo/yeo jida] (Become)
short_explanation: Shows a change in state or condition, 'become' or 'get'.
long_explanation: '아/어/여 지다' describes a transformation from one state to another over time. It’s often used with descriptive verbs (adjectives) to mean 'become + adjective' (e.g., 춥다 → 추워지다 for 'to become cold'). The choice of 아/어/여 depends on the stem’s final vowel.

examples.kr: 하늘이 어두워져서 길이 잘 안 보여요. 가게까지 가기 힘들겠어요.
examples.romaji: Haneuri eoduwojyeoseo giri jal an boyeoyo. GagekKaji gagi himdeulgesseoyo.
examples.en: The sky became dark, so it’s hard to see the road. Going to the store might be difficult.

examples.kr: 날씨가 추워져서 나가기가 싫어졌어요. 집에만 있고 싶네요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga chuwojyeoseo nagagiga sil-eojyeosseoyo. Jibeman itgo sipneyo.
examples.en: The weather got cold, so I don’t want to go outside. I just want to stay home.

examples.kr: 오늘은 힘든 일이 있어서 기분이 좋아지지 않았어요. 잠시 쉬면서 기분 전환하는 게 어떨까요?
examples.romaji: Oneureun himdeun iri isseoseo gibuni joajiji anasseoyo. Jamsi swieomyeonseo gibun jeonhwanhaneun ge eotteolkayo?
examples.en: I had a hard day today, so my mood hasn’t improved. How about taking a break to refresh yourself?

examples.kr: 친구 덕분에 기분이 한결 좋아졌어요. 자주 만나야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Chingu deokbune gibuni hangyeol joajyeosseoyo. Jaju mannayagesseoyo.
examples.en: Thanks to my friend, my mood got much better. I should see them more often.

title: 아/어/여 가지다 [a/eo/yeo gajida] (Have, possess)
short_explanation: Used when someone possesses or has certain qualities, traits, or characteristics.
long_explanation: '아/어/여 가지다' signifies that someone or something 'has' or 'possesses' a particular feature, quality, or characteristic. It’s often used with adjectives or abstract qualities, indicating the subject is endowed with or exhibits those traits.

examples.kr: 그녀는 아름다운 눈을 가지고 있어요. 밤하늘 별처럼 반짝여요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun areumdaun nuneul gajigo isseoyo. Bamhaneul byeolcheoreom banjjakyeoyo.
examples.en: She has beautiful eyes that sparkle like stars in the night sky.

examples.kr: 저는 좋은 친구를 많이 가지고 있어서 외롭지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun joeun chingureul manhi gajigo isseoseo oeropji anhayo.
examples.en: I have many good friends, so I’m never lonely.

examples.kr: 우리 회사는 강력한 경쟁력을 가져야 해요. 그래야 성장할 수 있거든요.
examples.romaji: Uri hoesaneun gangnyeokhan gyeongjaengryeogeul gajyeoya haeyo. Geuraeya seongjanghal su itgeodeunyo.
examples.en: Our company needs to have strong competitiveness; that’s the only way we can grow.

examples.kr: 그는 뛰어난 능력을 가지고 있어서 어떤 일이든 잘 해낼 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun ttwieonan neungnyeogeul gajigo isseoseo eotteon irideun jal haenael su isseoyo.
examples.en: He has outstanding abilities, so he can accomplish anything.

title: (으)ㄴ/는 편이다 [(eu)n/neun pyeonida] (Tend to)
short_explanation: Used to describe someone's tendency, habit, or general characteristic.
long_explanation: The expression '(으)ㄴ/는 편이다' describes a tendency or inclination. **With descriptive verbs (adjectives), you use (으)ㄴ 편이다**, and **with action verbs, you use 는 편이다**. It translates roughly to 'I tend to…' or 'It’s rather…'. It suggests that something is generally or somewhat the case, without being absolute.
formation: Descriptive verb + (으)ㄴ 편이다 / Action verb + 는 편이다

examples.kr: 그는 일찍 일어나는 편이에요. 주말에도 항상 아침 일찍 일어나요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun iljjik ireonaneun pyeonieyo. Jumal-edo hangsang achim iljjik ireonayo.
examples.en: He tends to wake up early. Even on weekends, he always gets up in the morning.

examples.kr: 저는 매운 음식을 잘 먹는 편이에요. 아주 매운 음식도 즐겨요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ma-eun eumsigeul jal meokneun pyeonieyo. Aju ma-eun eumsikdo jeulgyeoyo.
examples.en: I tend to handle spicy food pretty well. I even enjoy very spicy dishes.

examples.kr: 우리 동생은 안전을 중시하는 편이에요, 그래서 항상 안전벨트를 착용해요.
examples.romaji: Uri dongsaengeun anjeoneul jungsihaneun pyeonieyo, geuraeseo hangsang anjeonbelteureul chakyonghaeyo.
examples.en: My younger sibling tends to place importance on safety, so he always wears a seatbelt.

examples.kr: 나는 책을 자주 읽는 편이에요, 특히 공상 과학 소설을 좋아해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chaekeul jaju ilkneun pyeonieyo, teukhi gongsang gwahak soseoreul joahaeyo.
examples.en: I tend to read books often, especially science fiction.

title: 는/은 데 [neun/eun de] (Situation or condition)
short_explanation: Used to describe or clarify a situation, often introducing contrasting or unexpected information.
long_explanation: '는/은 데' serves as a connector in Korean. It provides context or background before introducing new or contrasting information. It can translate loosely to '…but…', '…and…', or '…so…' in English, depending on context. The form uses '는 데' for action verbs and '은 데' for descriptive verbs or nouns.

examples.kr: 아직 학생인데 돈을 벌려고 아르바이트를 하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Ajik haksaeng-inde don-eul beollyeogo areubaiteureul hago isseoyo.
examples.en: I'm still a student, but I'm working a part-time job to make money.

examples.kr: 어제 내가 집에 왔는데 아무도 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Eoje naega jibe watneunde amudo eobseosseoyo.
examples.en: I came home yesterday, but there was nobody there.

examples.kr: 지금 비가 오는데 우산을 안 가져와서 큰일이에요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum biga oneunde usaneul an gajyeowaseo keunirieyo.
examples.en: It's raining now, but I didn't bring an umbrella, which is problematic.

examples.kr: 저는 사람들과 얘기하는 것을 좋아하는데, 부끄러움이 많아서 어렵습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun saramdeulgwa yaegihaneun geoseul joahaneunde, bukkeureoumi manaseo eoryeopseumnida.
examples.en: I like talking to people, but it's difficult because I'm very shy.

title: 아/어/여야겠다 [a/eo/yeoya getda] (Should, must)
short_explanation: Expresses necessity or a decision that the speaker has reached; 'I should', 'I must'.
long_explanation: '아/어/여야겠다' is used when the speaker concludes that a certain action is necessary or desirable. It can translate to 'I should…', 'I must…', or 'I’d better…'. It expresses the speaker’s judgment or resolution about the action that needs to be taken.

examples.kr: 이 레포트를 빨리 완성해야겠어요. 제출 기한이 내일이거든요.
examples.romaji: I repoteureul ppalli wanseonghaeyagetseoyo. Jesul gihan-i naeirigodeunyo.
examples.en: I should finish this report quickly because the deadline is tomorrow.

examples.kr: 우리는 시간이 없으니까 택시를 타야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun sigani eopseunikka taeksireul tayagetseoyo.
examples.en: We should take a taxi since we don’t have much time.

examples.kr: 이 음식이 맛있어 보이니까, 나도 한 번 먹어 봐야겠어요.
examples.romaji: I eumsigi masisseo boinikka, nado han beon meogeo bwayagetseoyo.
examples.en: This food looks delicious. I should try it once, too.

examples.kr: 날씨가 추워서 더 따뜻한 옷을 입어야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga chuwoseo deo ttatteuthan oseul ibeoyagetseoyo.
examples.en: Because it’s cold, I should wear warmer clothes.

title: 아/어/여서는 안 되다 [a/eo/yeoseoneun an doeda] (Must not, shouldn't)
short_explanation: Used to express prohibition; 'must not', 'shouldn’t'.
long_explanation: The construction '아/어/여서는 안 되다' conveys that a certain action is forbidden or must not happen. It’s similar to 'You must not…' or 'You shouldn’t…' in English. Typically, we use the verb stem, attach 아/어/여서, and then add '는 안 되다.'
formation: Verb stem + 아/어/여서 + 는 안 되다

examples.kr: 이 병원에서는 담배를 피워서는 안 됩니다. 건강에 매우 해롭습니다.
examples.romaji: I byeongwoneseoneun dambaereul piwoseoneun an doemnida. Geongange maeu haeropseumnida.
examples.en: You must not smoke in this hospital. It’s very harmful to health.

examples.kr: 비밀인 사실을 다른 사람에게 말해서는 안 됩니다. 신뢰를 잃을 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Bimilin sasireul dareun saramege malhaeseoneun an doemnida. Sinloereul il-eul su isseoyo.
examples.en: You must not reveal a secret fact to others. You could lose their trust.

examples.kr: 시험 중에는 친구와 대화해서는 안 됩니다. 불공정한 행위로 간주될 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Siheom jungeneun chinguwa daehwahaseoneun an doemnida. Bulgongjeonghan haengwiro ganjudoel su isseoyo.
examples.en: You must not talk with a friend during an exam. It can be considered cheating.

examples.kr: 숙제를 너무 빨리 해서는 안 돼요. 이해가 안 되면 꼭 선생님께 질문해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Sukjereul neomu ppalli haeseoneun an dwaeyo. Ihaega an doemyeon kkok seonsaengnimkke jilmunhaeya haeyo.
examples.en: You shouldn’t rush through your homework. If you don’t understand something, you must ask the teacher.

title: 아/어/여 주세요 [a/eo/yeo juseyo] (Please give/do for me)
short_explanation: Politely request or command someone to do something for you.
long_explanation: '아/어/여 주세요' is used in Korean to make a **polite request** to the listener, akin to 'please do (something)' or 'please give me (something).' It attaches to the stem of an **action verb**, and the exact form (아/어/여) depends on the final vowel in the verb stem.

examples.kr: 같이 머물 수 있는 곳을 찾아 주세요. 제 친구와 함께 한국을 여행하고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Gachi meomul su inneun goseul chaja juseyo. Je chinguwa hamkke Hanguk-eul yeohaenghago sip-eoyo.
examples.en: Please find a place where we can stay together. I want to travel to Korea with my friend.

examples.kr: 이 문장에서 틀린 부분을 찾아 주세요. 제가 몰라서 도움이 필요해요.
examples.romaji: I munjang-eseo teullin bubuneul chaja juseyo. Jega mollaseo doumi pilyohaeyo.
examples.en: Please find the wrong part in this sentence. I need help because I don't know.

examples.kr: 집에 가는 길에 우유를 사 와 주세요. 집에 우유가 부족해요.
examples.romaji: Jibe ganeun gil-e uyureul sa wa juseyo. Jibe uyuga bujokhaeyo.
examples.en: Please buy milk on your way home. We're short on milk at home.

examples.kr: 이 메일에 답장을 보내 주세요. 곧 답변이 필요해요.
examples.romaji: I meile dapjangeul bonae juseyo. Got dapbyeoni pilyohaeyo.
examples.en: Please send a reply to this email. I need a response soon.

title: 아/어/여 드리다 [a/eo/yeo deurida] (To give – honorific)
short_explanation: Conveys politeness when doing something for someone (honorific).
long_explanation: '아/어/여 드리다' is an **honorific** version of '아/어/여 주다' used to **politely express** that you are doing (or giving) something to someone of higher status or to show respect. It follows the same vowel rules as '주다', but replaces '주다' with '드리다' for heightened politeness.

examples.kr: 알려 드리기 위해 제 전화번호를 당신에게 드립니다.
examples.romaji: Allyeo deurigi wihae je jeonhwa-beonhoreul dangsinege deurimnida.
examples.en: I give you my phone number to inform you.

examples.kr: 고객님께 더 좋은 서비스를 제공해 드리고자 항상 노력하고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Gogaengnimkke deo jo-eun seobiseureul jegonghae deurigoja hangsang noryeokhago issseumnida.
examples.en: We are always striving to provide better service to our valued customers.

examples.kr: 어머니께 편지를 써 드렸습니다.
examples.romaji: Eomeonikke pyeonjireul sseodeuryeosseumnida.
examples.en: I wrote a letter for my mother.

examples.kr: 학생들에게 좋은 지식을 가르쳐 드리지 않을 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Haksaengdeurege jo-eun jisigeul gareuchyeo deuriji anheul su eopseoyo.
examples.en: I can't help but impart good knowledge to my students.

title: 다니다 [danida] (To attend, go regularly)
short_explanation: Used to express attending or regularly going to a place.
long_explanation: '다니다' means to **go (somewhere) regularly** or to **attend**. It conveys habitual or routine movement. Examples include attending school or work daily, going to the gym regularly, etc.
formation: Noun + 에 다니다 (often a place, like '학교에 다니다')

examples.kr: 저는 매일 아침 일찍 운동하러 체육관에 다녔더니 습관이 되었어요. 그래서 체력이 좋아졌어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeil achim iljjik undonghareo cheyukgwane danyeottdeoni seupgwani doeeosseoyo. Geuraeseo cheryeogi joajyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I got into the habit of going to the gym early every morning for exercise, so my stamina improved.

examples.kr: 수업을 듣기 위해 학생들은 매일 학교에 다녀야 합니다. 그래야 공부를 제대로 할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Sueobeul deutgi wihae haksaengdeureun maeil hakgyoe danyeoya hamnida. Geuraeya gongbureul jedaero hal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Students need to attend school daily to take classes. Only then can they study well.

examples.kr: 나는 친구들과 주말마다 카페에 다니면서 즐거운 시간을 보냈어요. 그래서 추억이 많아요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chingudeulgwa jumalmada kapee danimyeonseo jeulgeoun siganeul bonaesseoyo. Geuraeseo chueogi manhayo.
examples.en: I spent time going to cafés with my friends on weekends, so I have lots of good memories.

examples.kr: 이 회사에서 일하려면 매일 사무실에 다녀야 해요. 그래야 업무를 처리할 수 있죠.
examples.romaji: I hoesaeseo ilharyeomyeon maeil samusile danyeoya haeyo. Geuraeya eommureul cheorihal su itjyo.
examples.en: To work at this company, you need to come to the office every day. That's how you can handle the work.

title: 아/어/여 가다 [a/eo/yeo gada] (Continue/keep doing something – away from the present)
short_explanation: Indicates an action continuing or moving away from the present point in time or space.
long_explanation: The expression '아/어/여 가다' can mean that **an action or state continues** in a forward direction—much like 'keep on ~ing' or 'go on ~ing.' It can also show that the action is moving away from the current context. (Note: If you want to say 'go somewhere to do something,' you typically use **'(으)러 가다'** instead.)

examples.kr: 날이 갈수록 날씨가 더 추워져 가고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Nari galsurok nalssiga deo chuwojyeo gago isseoyo.
examples.en: As the days go by, it keeps getting colder.

examples.kr: 점점 실력이 늘어 가는 것 같아서 기뻐요.
examples.romaji: Jeomjeom sillyeogi neureo ganeun geot gataseo gippeoyo.
examples.en: I’m happy because it seems like my skills are gradually improving.

examples.kr: 계속 연습해 가면 언젠가 프로가 될 수 있을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Gyesok yeonseuphae gamyeon eonjenga peuroga doel su isseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: If you keep practicing, you can eventually turn pro.

examples.kr: 그 문제에 대해 생각해 가면서 차근차근 해결책을 찾고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geu munje-e daehae saenggakhae gamyeonseo chageunchageun haegyeolchaegeul chatgo isseoyo.
examples.en: I’m gradually thinking over the problem and looking for a solution step by step.

title: (으)러 가다/오다 [(eu)reo gada/oda] (Go/come in order to do)
short_explanation: Indicates going or coming somewhere for the purpose of performing an action.
long_explanation: '(으)러 가다/오다' is used when you physically **go** or **come** to a location in order to do something. The form is '(으)러' for verbs whose stems end in a consonant (other than ㄹ), and '러' if the stem ends in a vowel or ㄹ. For example, '공부하러 가다' = to go somewhere to study.

examples.kr: 저는 이번 주말에 영화를 보러 가려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ibeon jumare yeonghwareul boreo garyeogo haeyo.
examples.en: I'm planning to go watch a movie this weekend.

examples.kr: 우리는 내일부터 공부하러 도서관에 갈 거예요.
examples.romaji: Urineun naeilbuteo gongbuhareo doseogwane gal geoyeyo.
examples.en: Starting tomorrow, we're going to the library to study.

examples.kr: 그녀는 이번 주에 친구들과 여행하러 고향에 갈 계획이에요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun ibeon jue chingudeulgwa yeohaenghareo gohyange gal gyehoegieyo.
examples.en: She’s planning to go to her hometown to travel with her friends this week.

examples.kr: 너무 배고파서 점심 먹으러 식당에 가려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Neomu baegopaseo jeomsim meogeureo sikdange garyeogo haeyo.
examples.en: I’m starving, so I’m going to head to a restaurant for lunch.

title: 아/어/여 오다 [a/eo/yeo oda] (Come to do / end up doing)
short_explanation: Expresses arriving at a certain action or state, or having done something up to now.
long_explanation: '아/어/여 오다' can mean 'to come doing something' (physically) or 'to do something gradually until now' (metaphorically). For literal movement, it's often '(으)러 오다' (e.g., 먹으러 오다 = 'come to eat'). For a figurative sense, it can describe an action that has progressed and continued up to the present, akin to 'have been doing.'
formation: Verb stem + (으)러 오다 (physical movement) or Verb stem + 아/어/여 오다 (continuing action up to the present)

examples.kr: 그 여우는 손바닥 위의 닭을 먹으러 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeouneun sonbadak wieui dalkeul meogeureo wasseoyo.
examples.en: That fox came to eat the chicken it saw on someone’s palm.

examples.kr: 방학이라서 친구들과 여행하러 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Banghagiraso chingudeulgwa yeohaenghareo wasseoyo.
examples.en: Since it's vacation, I came here to travel with my friends.

examples.kr: 다이어트를 시작해서 아침마다 달리기를 해 오고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Daieoteureul sijakhaeseo achimmada dalligireul hae ogo isseoyo.
examples.en: I started a diet, so I’ve been running every morning.

examples.kr: 너무 많이 먹었더니 한참 걸어 오느라 겨우 집에 도착했어요.
examples.romaji: Neomu manhi meogeotdeoni hancham georeo oneura gyeou jibe dochakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I ate too much, so I walked for a long time and only just arrived home.

title: 고 있다 [go itda] (To be doing)
short_explanation: Indicates a continuous or ongoing action, similar to the English '-ing' form.
long_explanation: '고 있다' is the standard way to express an **action in progress**. For example, '읽고 있다' = 'am reading,' '요리하고 있다' = 'am cooking.' It differs from '아/어 있다,' which usually describes a **resultant state** (e.g., '앉아 있다' = 'to be seated').

examples.kr: 나는 지금 책을 읽고 있어요. 그래서 나중에 스터디 그룹에 참여하려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun jigeum chaekeul ilgo isseoyo. Geuraeseo najunge seuteodi geurupe chamyuharyeogo haeyo.
examples.en: I’m reading a book right now, so I plan to join a study group later.

examples.kr: 엄마는 요리하고 있어요. 그래서 나는 방에 있어서 도와줄 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Eommaneun yorihago isseoyo. Geuraeseo naneun bange isseoseo dowajul su eopseoyo.
examples.en: My mom is cooking, so I’m in my room and can’t help her.

examples.kr: 오빠는 혼자서 연습하고 있어요. 나는 그를 방해하지 않으려고 조용히 있어요.
examples.romaji: Oppaneun honjaseo yeonseubhago isseoyo. Naneun geureul banghaehaji anh-euryeogo joyonghi isseoyo.
examples.en: My brother is practicing alone; I’m staying quiet so I don’t disturb him.

examples.kr: 친구들은 축구를 하고 있어요. 그런데 비가 와서 이제 그만두려고 하네요.
examples.romaji: Chingudeureun chukgureul hago isseoyo. Geureonde biga waseo ije geumanduryeogo haneyo.
examples.en: My friends are playing soccer, but since it started to rain, they’re about to stop now.

title: 아/어/여 보다 [a/eo/yeo boda] (Try to do)
short_explanation: Expresses an attempt or trial to do something, 'try doing'.
long_explanation: '아/어/여 보다' indicates that you **attempt** or **try** an action to see what happens. It can be used for trying something for the first time or experimenting with a new method. In English, it corresponds to 'try ~ing' or 'give it a try.'

examples.kr: 새로운 요리법을 배웠으니 오늘 저녁 식사를 해 보려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Saeroun yoribeobeul baewosseuni oneul jeonyeok siksareul hae boryeogo hamnida.
examples.en: Since I learned a new cooking method, I’m going to try making dinner tonight.

examples.kr: 영어 배우는 게 어렵지만 계속 공부해 보려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Yeongeo baeuneun ge eoryeopjiman gyesok gongbuhae boryeogo haeyo.
examples.en: Learning English is hard, but I intend to keep trying.

examples.kr: 아이들에게 로봇 공학을 가르쳐 볼 건데, 어려워하지 않을지 모르겠네요.
examples.romaji: Aideurege robot gonghageul gareuchyeo bol geonde, eoryeowohaji anheulji moreugessneyo.
examples.en: I'm going to try teaching robotics to the kids, but I’m not sure if they'll find it difficult.

examples.kr: 이 가방이 맞는지 확인하려면 직접 들고 다녀 보아야 해요.
examples.romaji: I gabangi matneunji hwaginharyeomyeon jikjeop deulgo danyo bo-aya haeyo.
examples.en: If you want to confirm whether this bag is right for you, you need to actually try carrying it around.
